{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2016}} {{campaignbox Sudanese nomadic conflicts}}
'''Ethnic violence in South Sudan''' has a long history among [[South Sudan]]'s varied [[Demographics of South Sudan#Ethnic groups|ethnic groups]]. South Sudan has 64 tribes<ref name=guardian1215/> with the largest being the [[Dinka people|Dinka]]s, who constitute about 35% of the population<ref name=cia>{{CIA World Factbook link|od|South Sudan}}</ref> and predominate in government. The second largest are the [[Nuer people|Nuer]]s. Conflict is often aggravated among nomadic groups over the issue of cattle and grazing land and is part of the wider [[Sudanese nomadic conflicts]].
In 2010, [[Dennis C. Blair|Dennis Blair]], then United States [[Director of National Intelligence]], issued a warning that "over the next five years,...a new mass killing or genocide is most likely to occur in southern Sudan."<ref name=Abramowitz>{{cite news | last = Abramowitz | first = Michael |author2=Lawrence Woocher | title = How Genocide Became a National Security Threat | work = Foreign Policy | accessdate = 2013-02-12 | date = 2010-02-26| url = https://foreignpolicy.com/articles/2010/02/26/how_genocide_became_a_national_security_threat }}</ref><ref name=aljazeera>{{cite news|title=Sudan: Transcending tribe |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/photo_galleries/africa/201111010324526960.html |work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |accessdate=30 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110317113359/http://english.aljazeera.net//photo_galleries/africa/201111010324526960.html |archivedate=17 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> In April 2017, [[Priti Patel]], the [[Secretary of State for International Development|Secretary]] of the United Kingdom's [[Department for International Development]], declared the violence in South Sudan as genocide.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/south-sudan-africa-genocide-uk-priti-patel-un-violence-a7681361.html|title=UK goes beyond UN to say South Sudan violence 'is now genocide'|date=12 April 2017|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=The Independent}}</ref>
{{TOC limit|3}}
== Background ==
===Nomadic raiding=== {{See also|Sudanese nomadic conflicts|Cattle raiding}} Those from the [[Murle people|Murle]] and the [[Lou Nuer]] are largely nomadic cattle herders. [[Cattle]] are used as food and are used as a store of wealth. It takes 20 cows to buy a bride if a young man hopes to marry, which encourages [[cattle raiding]]. Violence between the two groups go back generations, exacerbated by tensions over land and water. The attacks often target an entire village, burning them in their round thatched huts. Militias frequently abduct children during cattle raids, who are then raised as their own. This is seen as a method, notably among the Murle, to increase the numbers of the small minority group. In past generations, attacks used machetes and sticks. However, after decades of civil war, the region is awash with guns, and young men are now armed with high-powered weapons.<ref name=latimes>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/africa/la-fg-ethiopia-massacre-20160420-story.html|title=Why hundreds of people are dying over cattle in East Africa|publisher=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=23 November 2016}}</ref> In 2017, local organizations said that more than 5,000 people were killed since 2011 in cattle raids in South Sudan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/02/south-sudan-cattle-raids-170205090102703.html|title=Thousands killed in cattle raids since 2011|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=5 February 2017|date=5 February 2017}}</ref>
===Sudan People's Liberation Army=== The governing party, the [[Sudan People's Liberation Movement]] (SPLM), and the army, the [[Sudan People's Liberation Army]] (SPLA), have been accused of being dominated by the Dinka. Many refer to the dominance of Dinkas as the "Dinkocracy".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2013/12/south-sudan-teeters-brink-20131217131843385823.html|title=South Sudan teeters on the brink|date=17 December 2013|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=Aljazeera}}</ref> A Dinka lobbying group known as the "Jieng Council of Elders" is often accused of being behind hardline SPLM policies.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/dinka-council-elders-welcomes-kiir’s-decision-firing-ministers-allied-machar|title=Dinka council of elders welcomes Kiir’s decision firing ministers allied to Machar|date=4 August 2016|accessdate=9 March 2017|work=Radio Tamazuj}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article59719|title=Jieng Council of Elders caused "coup" in SPLM-IO: official|date=24 July 2015|accessdate=9 March 2017|work=Sudan Tribune}}</ref> While the army used to attract men from across tribes, during the South Sudanese Civil War, the SPLA had largely become a militia of soldiers from the Dinka stronghold of [[Bahr el Ghazal (region of South Sudan)|Bahr el Ghazal]], home region of President Kiir and the Chief of Staff,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/20/opinion/south-sudan-cannot-be-allowed-to-collapse.html?_r=1|title=South Sudan must not be allowed to collapse|date=20 January 2017|publisher=New York Times}}</ref> and the army was often referred to within the country as "the Dinka army".<ref name=bbcnews0317/> Much of the worst atrocities committed are blamed on a group known as "[[Mathiang Anyoor]]" (Brown caterpillar) or "Dot Ke Beny" (Rescue the President), a militia of Dinkas formed to protect Kiir and [[Paul Malong Awan]], while the SPLA claim that it is just another battalion.<ref name=africanarguments>{{cite web|url=http://africanarguments.org/2016/07/11/whos-behind-south-sudans-return-to-fighting/|title=Who's behind South Sudan's return to fighting?|date=11 July 2016|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=African arguments}}</ref><ref name=bbcnews0317>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-39209280|title=South Sudan conflict: 'Soldiers will kill you for no reason in Yei'|first=Alastair|last=Leithead|date=9 March 2017|accessdate=9 March 2017|work=BBC}}</ref>
===South Sudan Democratic Movement=== The [[South Sudan Democratic Movement]] (SSDM) is a rebel group founded in 2010 by [[George Athor]] after he lost a contested election. The group also incorporates and supports other factions as part of a broad coalition of those who complain of neglect by the Dinka dominated SPLA. This notably includes those composed of ethnic minorities such as the [[Murle people]] who lead the Cobra faction and the [[Shilluk people]] who lead the Upper Nile Faction. In a strategy of co-option known as "big tent", the government often buys off community militia and pardons its leaders.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irinnews.org/analysis/2016/10/12/south-sudans-never-ending-war|title=South Sudan's never ending war.|date=12 October 2016|publisher=Irinnews}}</ref> Others call the use of rebellion to receive public office as "bad culture"<ref name=voa2>{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/a/militant-faction-vows-again-to-fight-south-sudan-government/3527442.html|title=Militant Faction Vows Again to Fight S. Sudan Government|date=27 September 2016|publisher=Voice of America}}</ref> and an incentive to rebel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bostonreview.net/world/mahmood-mamdani-south-sudan-failed-transition|title=Who's to blame in South Sudan?|date=28 June 2016|publisher=Boston Review}}</ref>
== Murle-Nuer fighting == ===Uror massacre (2011)=== On 18 August 2011, an attack in Uror County, northern [[Jonglei]] was reportedly launched by Murle tribesmen after armed groups infiltrated into the Peiri and Pulchuol Districts (Payams) at about 5 a.m. The attack is believed to have been a revenge operation against the Lou Nuer tribe after an attack on the Murle the previous June in Pibor County. At least 640 people were killed and the attackers burned down over 3,400 houses and the hospital run by [[Médecins Sans Frontières]]. An initial estimate showed that 38,000 heads of cattle were stolen and 208 children were kidnapped.<ref name=TribuneCattle>{{cite web|title=Hundreds dead' in South Sudan cattle raids |url=http://www.sudantribune.com/Hundreds-killed-in-South-Sudan-s,39887 |publisher=Sudan Tribune |accessdate=23 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110829155651/http://www.sudantribune.com/Hundreds-killed-in-South-Sudan-s,39887 |archivedate=29 August 2011 }}</ref>
===Pibor massacre (2011-2012)=== [[File:Nuer White Army Flag.svg|thumb|Nuer White Army flag]] {{Main|Pibor massacre}} By 25 December 2011, the [[Nuer White Army]] released a statement stating its intent to "[[genocide|wipe out]] the entire Murle tribe on the face of the earth as the only solution to guarantee long-term security of Nuer's cattle" and attack [[United Nations]] and SPLA personnel if they interfered.<ref name=bloomberg>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-12-27/united-nations-urges-south-sudan-to-help-avert-possible-attack.html|title=United Nations Urges South Sudan to Help Avert Possible Attack|first=Jared|last=Ferrie|date=27 December 2011|accessdate=27 December 2011|work=Bloomberg}}</ref> The [[United Nations Mission in South Sudan]] (UNMISS) deployed peacekeepers to Pibor on 30 December in an effort to avert an attack by 6,000 armed Lou Nuer youths. [[United Nations]] Secretary-General [[Ban Ki-moon]] and UNMISS head [[Hilde Johnson]] called on Lou Nuer and Murle fighters alike to lay down their arms and allow the [[government of South Sudan]] to work with them toward a lasting solution to the crisis.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=40863&Cr=south+sudan&Cr1=|agency=UN News Service|title=South Sudan: UN blue helmets deploy to deter ethnic violence in key town|date=30 December 2011|accessdate=30 December 2011}}</ref> Activists, including [[Minority Rights Group International]], warned of genocide in the conflict.<ref name=sudantribune2>{{cite news|title=Activists warn of "genocide" in S.Sudan's Jonglei conflict |first= |last= |url=http://www.sudantribune.com/Activists-warn-of-genocide-in-S,41011 |work=[[Sudan Tribune]] |date=16 December 2011 |accessdate=2 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111229111823/https://www.sudantribune.com/Activists-warn-of-genocide-in-S,41011 |archivedate=29 December 2011 }}</ref>
At 3 pm on 31 December between 3–6,000 Lou Nuer tribesmen attacked a part of Pibor not protected by the UN peacekeepers.<ref name=stjan>{{cite news|title=BREAKING NEWS: Lou-Nuer armed youth enter Pibor town |url=http://www.sudantribune.com/BREAKING-NEWS-Lou-Nuer-armed-youth,41143 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |newspaper=Sudan Tribune |date=31 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111231170544/http://www.sudantribune.com/BREAKING-NEWS-Lou-Nuer-armed-youth,41143 |archivedate=31 December 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Kushkush|first=Isma'il|title=Report: Fighters attack South Sudan town despite presence of U.N. peacekeepers|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/01/01/world/africa/south-sudan-violence/?hpt=wo_c2|accessdate=1 January 2012|newspaper=CNN|date=1 January 2012}}</ref> Houses were reported to have been set on fire and much of the town, including the airport and main hospital, were occupied.<ref name=stjan /> The Lou Nuer were said to have pursued members of the Murle who were fleeing southwards.<ref name=bbcjan>{{cite news|title=South Sudan 'sends more troops' to strife-torn town Pibor|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-16377824|accessdate=1 January 2012|newspaper=BBC News|date=1 January 2012}}</ref> The South Sudanese government promised to send more army personnel and 2,000 police to the town to reinforce the 800 troops already there.<ref name=bbcjan /><ref>{{cite news|title=MSF fears for South Sudan staff caught in Pibor violence|url=http://www.portalangop.co.ao/motix/en_us/noticias/africa/2012/0/52/MSF-fears-for-South-Sudan-staff-caught-Pibor-violence,b8ebc0aa-d586-430b-82cb-3761c85e3c0b.html|accessdate=1 January 2012|newspaper=Angola Press|date=1 January 2012}}</ref> The healthcare charity [[Médecins Sans Frontières]] (MSF) said that it lost contact with 130 of its staff who were forced to flee into the bush due to the attack.<ref name=bbcjan /> MSF said that a hospital and two outreach clinics were overrun, with some reports stating that the hospital had been set on fire.<ref name=telegraphjan>{{cite news|last=Squires|first=Nick|title=Fears for MSF staff after South Sudan tribal clashes|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/south-sudan/8987065/Fears-for-MSF-staff-after-South-Sudan-tribal-clashes.html|accessdate=2 January 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=2 January 2012|location=London}}</ref> Looting was said to have taken place at MSF facilities.<ref name=telegraphjan />
By 2 January, the majority of the Lou Nuer forces were said to have left Pibor and started to move to the southeast with a UN spokesman saying they were "almost certainly looking for cattle".<ref name=bbc2jan>{{cite news|title=UN warns South Sudanese to flee deadly ethnic vendetta|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-16381579|accessdate=2 January 2012|publisher=BBC News|date=2 January 2012}}</ref> The UN said that it had successfully held the main part of Pibor alongside South Sudanese army troops.<ref name=bbc2jan /> The UN was advising people in the area to "disperse into the bush for their safety".<ref name=bbc2jan /> Estimates for the number of displaced ranged up to 50,000, and more than 30 were killed with as many as 80 left injured. The SPLA dispatched 3,000 soldiers and 800 police to support the government's garrison in Pibor.<ref name=aje>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2012/01/201212101840599359.html|agency=Al Jazeera|date=2 January 2012|accessdate=2 January 2012|title=Thousands flee South Sudan tribal conflict}}</ref> On 5 January, Joshua Konyi, the commissioner of [[Pibor County]] and a Murle, estimated that 2,182 women and children and 959 men were killed, 1,293 children were abducted, and 375,186 cows were stolen.<ref name=NYT2>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/06/world/africa/in-south-sudan-massacre-of-3000-is-reported.html?_r=1&ref=global-home|title=In South Sudan, Massacre of 3,000 is reported|last=Gettleman|first=Jeffrey|date=5 January 2012|accessdate=6 January 2012|agency=New York Times|work=The New York Times}}</ref> The United Nations estimated a total death toll of 900 between December 2011 and February 2012 as a result of the Nuer-Murle clashes, prior to the South Sudanese government's disarmament campaign in March.<ref>{{cite web|title=World Report 2013: South Sudan (Events of 2012)|url=https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2013/country-chapters/south-sudan|publisher=Human Rights Watch|accessdate=18 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://unmiss.unmissions.org/sites/default/files/june_2012_jonglei_report.pdf|title=Incidents of intercommunal violence in Jonglei state|publisher=UNMISS|accessdate=23 November 2016}}</ref>
A peace deal was signed in May 2012 by representatives of six ethnic communities in Jonglei state.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article42504|title=President Kiir witnesses signing of Jonglei peace deal|date=5 May 2012|accessdate=21 January 2017|work=Sudan Tribune}}</ref>
===Akobo county attack (2013)=== In February 2013, an attack by a group of armed Murle youth killed more than 100 civilians<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article45533|title=Jonglei: MSF treats civilians wounded in Akobo county attack |publisher=Sudan Tribune|accessdate=21 January 2017}}</ref> and 14 SPLA soldiers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article45461|title=Jonglei: Hundreds feared dead or missing in Akobo county attack |publisher=Sudan Tribune|accessdate=21 January 2017}}</ref>
===South Sudanese Civil War=== The [[South Sudan Democratic Movement#SSDM/A - Cobra Faction|Greater Pibor Forces]] split off from the [[South Sudan Democratic Movement#SSDM/A - Cobra Faction|Cobra Faction]], which had signed a peace agreement with the government. They joined opposition forces and one of their disagreements with the government was the alleged encouragement of the Murle, as a method of divide and rule, to fight against Nuer groups in Jonglei, as some groups such as the Nuer White Army have fought against the government.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article53980|title=Murle faction announces defection to S. Sudan rebels|publisher=Sudan Tribune|accessdate=18 January 2017|date=14 February 2015}}</ref>
====2016 Gambela raid==== On 15 April 2016, [[Murle people|Murle]] fighters in South Sudan crossed over to the Jikawo and Lare areas of the [[Gambela Region]] (which hosts about 300,000 South Sudanese refugees) in [[Ethiopia]] and killed at least 208 people, stole 2000 cattle and kidnapped at least 108 women and children from the [[Nuer people|Nuer]] tribe.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Reporters|first1=The Telegraph|title=Armed men massacre 140 civilians in Ethiopia cross-border raid|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/04/17/armed-men-massacre-140-civilians-in-ethiopia-cross-border-raid/|accessdate=18 April 2016|date=17 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Ethiopia army seeks to rescue Gambella's abducted children|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-36071090|accessdate=18 April 2016|work=BBC}}</ref> Ethiopian troops killed about 60 gunmen and crossed over the border with the South Sudanese government's permission to track the kidnappers in what some felt is the spilling over of fighting into Ethiopia.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/blogs/africa/2016/04/ethiopia-attack-wife-child-ran-160422164613438.html|title=Ethiopia attack: 'I took my wife and child and ran'|publisher=aljazeera|accessdate=18 July 2016|date=22 April 2016}}</ref> By 2017, about 100 children had been retrieved.<ref name=aje0317/>
====2017 Gambela raid==== In March 2017, about 1,000 Murle gunmen from [[Boma State]] raided the Gambela Region in Ethiopia and abducted 43 children. They were pursued by the Ethiopian military.<ref name=aje0317>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/03/ethiopia-reports-deadly-raid-gunmen-south-sudan-170315130515870.html|title=Ethiopia reports deadly raid by gunmen from South Sudan|publisher=aljazeera|accessdate=17 March 2017|date=15 March 2017}}</ref>
== Dinka-Nuer fighting ==
===Second Sudanese Civil War=== During the [[Second Sudanese Civil War]], several factions split from the SPLA often along ethnic lines and were funded and armed by Khartoum.<ref name=Time1>{{cite news|url=http://content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2048788,00.html|title=Deadly clashes on South Sudan's path to freedom|publisher=time.com|accessdate=21 December 2013|date=12 February 2011}}</ref> The most notable was [[SPLA-Nasir]] founded in 1991 by [[Riek Machar]] as an attempt by the Nuer to replace [[John Garang]].
The [[South Sudan Liberation Movement]] (SSLA) was formed in 1999 as a Nuer dominated faction in the Civil War.
====Bor massacre (1991)==== {{Main|Bor massacre}} As a result of the infighting, more southerners died at each other's hands than were killed by northerners during the war.<ref name=Time1/> In the [[Bor massacre]] in 1991, an estimated 2000 civilians were killed by SPLA-Nasir and the [[Nuer White Army]] and another estimated 25,000 died from the resulting famine in the following years.<ref name=eveningpost>{{cite news|url=http://www.thelondoneveningpost.com/riek-machar-breaks-down-in-tears-as-he-admits-to-1991-bor-massacres/|title=Riek Machar in tears as he admits to 1991 Bor massacres|publisher=thelondoneveningpost.com|accessdate=20 December 2013|date=16 August 2011}}</ref>
===South Sudanese Civil War=== [[File:Flag of the South Sudan Liberation Movement.svg|thumb|SSLM flag]] In April 2011, The SSLA, now led by [[Peter Gadet]], announces its formation as a rebel army fighting against the main SPLA forces.<ref name=BusinessW /> In 2011, SSLA clash with tribal cattle herders in [[Warrap (state)|Warrap State]], south of Abyei. Southern authorities accuse the rebels of being backed by al-Bashir's Khartoum government, and say that the rebels are mobilizing the Misseriya against the SPLA in Unity State.<ref name=BusinessW>{{cite news|last=Richmond|first=Matthew|title=Southern Sudan Clashes in Warrap State Kill 72, Army Says|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-05-10/southern-sudan-clashes-in-warrap-state-kill-72-army-says.html|accessdate=7 January 2012|newspaper=BusinessWeek|date=10 May 2011}}{{dead link|date=November 2015}}</ref> To put down the rebellion, it was alleged that the SPLA set fire to over 7,000 homes in Unity state in May 2011.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article39010|title=SPLA set fire to over 7,000 homes in Unity says Mayom county official|publisher=Sudan Tribune|accessdate=17 January 2017|date=24 May 2011}}</ref>
====Anti-Nuer pogroms (2013)==== In 2013, after a year of escalating changes in government and in the party, including the dismissal of Vice-President [[Riek Machar]] and the entire cabinet in June, fighting between Nuer and Dinka SPLA soldiers broke out in Juba on December, igniting the South Sudanese Civil War. A rebellion rapidly spread around the country, with defected troops loyal to Machar and the SSLA taking over Bentiu, Malakal and Bor.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/south-sudan-president-says-coup-repulsed-124616535.html|title=South Sudan president says coup has been repulsed|date=16 December 2013|work=Yahoo News|accessdate=26 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-25480178 | work=BBC News | title=South Sudan rebel Riek Machar 'controls key state' | date=22 December 2013}}</ref>
Immediately after the initial mutiny in Juba, Nuer soldiers, overpowered and on the run, made off toward Terekeka, north of Juba, leaving no Nuer soldiers left in the city. SPLM Dinka troops, led by Lieutenant General Marial Chanuong,<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-southsudan-security-un-idUSKBN18K2RH| work=Reuters| title=U.S., Britain, U.N. wary of South Sudan ceasefire announcement| date=24 May 2017|accessdate=15 June 2017}}</ref> were assisted by guides in house to house searches for Nuers in Nuer areas of the Juba.<ref name="hrw.org"/> In the Gudele neighborhood, about 200-400 Nuer men were rounded up in to a room in a police station and were shot at through the windows over two days if the soldiers noticed signs of life.<ref name="theguardian.com">{{Citation | title = South Sudan, the state that fell apart in a week | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/dec/23/south-sudan-state-that-fell-apart-in-a-week | date = 2013-12-23 | newspaper = The Guardian | place = [[United Kingdom|UK]]}}</ref> There were about 12 survivors.<ref name="massethnic">{{cite web| first = James | last = Copnall|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-25502457 |title=South Sudan sees 'mass ethnic killings' | publisher = BBC|date= 24 December 2013 |accessdate= 24 December 2013}}</ref><ref name="radiotamazuj.org">{{Citation | title = UN rights chief zeroes on Gudele massacre | publisher = Ratio Tamazuj | url = https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/un-rights-chief-zeroes-gudele-massacre}}</ref> An African Union report cited Nuers being tortured, such as being forced to eat human flesh and blood and to jump into fires.<ref name=aje1015>{{cite news|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2015/10/28/report-mass-graves-rape-cannibalism-in-south-sudan.html|title=Mass Graves, Rape Cannibalism in South Sudan|date=28 October 2015|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=Al Jazeera}}</ref> Official death toll has not been released as Human Rights Watch has noted the South Sudan government troops had blocked access and were heavily guarding Gudele and other affected, now abandoned suburbs of Juba.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{Citation | title = Dispatches: the truth on limits: Juba, South Sudan | date = 2014-02-18 | url = https://www.hrw.org/news/2014/02/18/dispatches-truth-limits-juba-south-sudan | publisher = Human Rights Watch}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA" /> The Guardian report also reported that 21 Nuer youths as well as three women were killed in two other incidents<ref name="theguardian.com" /> while Human Rights Watch cites eye witness accounts of truck loads of bodies carried to undisclosed site on December 18, 2013.<ref name="hrw.org">{{Citation | title = South Sudan: ethnic targeting, widespread killings | url = https://www.hrw.org/news/2014/01/16/south-sudan-ethnic-targeting-widespread-killings | publisher = Human Rights Watch}}</ref> Government officials have not announced a list of the dead or the location of the bodies<ref name="ReferenceA" /> and have denied knowledge of any killings.<ref name="radiotamazuj.org" /> Much of the killings were carried out by [[Mathiang Anyoor]].<ref name="africanarguments"/><ref name=aje1015/> Similar door to door searches of members of the Nuer ethnicity have been reported in the government held capital city of the Upper Nile State, Malakal.<ref>{{Citation |url=https://news.yahoo.com/sudan-troops-39-door-door-39-seized-town-215351156.html |title=Sudan troops go ‘door to door’ in seized town |publisher=Yahoo |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140126065608/http://news.yahoo.com/sudan-troops-39-door-door-39-seized-town-215351156.html |archivedate=26 January 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
====Bentiu massacre (2014)==== {{Main|2014 Bentiu massacre}} During the [[South Sudanese Civil War]], forces identified by the UN as SPLM-IO massacred about 200 mostly non-Nuer civilians in April 2014.
====Mapel massacre (2014)==== {{Main|2014 retreat from Western Bahr el Ghazal}} On 25 April, ethnic tensions between Nuer trainees of the SPLA and Dinka civilians escalated in Mapel, at the time part of [[Western Bahr el Ghazal]], resulting in altercations and murders. In response, Dinka soldiers of the SPLA's 5th Division, led by Bak Akoon Bak, massacred their Nuer comrades at the local training center, killing between 40 to 200 Nuer. The surviving Nuer soldiers fled into [[the bush]], with some joining local SPLM-IO rebels or starting to escape northward. Joined by hundreds of other Nuer deserters from [[Wau, South Sudan|Wau]] and later [[Northern Bahr el Ghazal]], the Nuer deserters [[2014 retreat from Western Bahr el Ghazal|marched all the way]] to [[Sudan]] to escape ethnic prosecution and loyalist SPLA forces.{{sfnp|Small Arms Survey|2014}}
== Murle-Dinka fighting ==
===Sudanese Civil Wars=== As early as 1963, during the [[First Sudanese Civil War]], Khartoum began arming the Murle tribe, traditional enemies of both Dinka and Nuer, to fight the southern rebellion. Sometimes, whole tribal territories became affiliated with one side or the other, and the vicious north-south war became a defining factor in relations between tribes, infusing old hostilities with a new, political dimension. With the peace deal in 2005, tribal militias chose to either be absorbed into the SPLA or head north and join the armed forces there. Most chose to join their former SPLA enemies as a matter of survival. Others, like fighters from the Murle tribe, chose to join the northern army. Today, there are many Murle army officers in Khartoum, and they say the tribe is being punished for that.<ref name=aljazeera/>
=== Cobra faction rebellion === [[File:Greater Pibor Administrative Area.svg|thumb|The [[Greater Pibor Administrative Area]] (highlighted) created as part of a peace agreement between the government and the largely [[Murle people|Murle]] rebel group, the [[South Sudan Democratic Movement#SSDM/A - Cobra Faction|Cobra Faction]], in 2014.]] [[File:Flag of the South Sudan Defence Army - Cobra Faction.svg|thumb|left|The flag of the Murle dominated Cobra Faction; a splinter of the wider SSDA, led by [[David Yau Yau]] and then by Khalid Boutros.]] [[David Yau Yau]], led a Murle dominated faction of the [[South Sudan Democratic Movement]] (SSDM) known as the [[South Sudan Democratic Movement#SSDM/A - Cobra Faction|Cobra faction]] against the government in 2010. He signed a ceasefire with the GoSS in June 2011, which integrated him and his militia with the SPLA. However, he defected again in April 2012 citing SPLA abuses in Pibor county in the March–October 2012 disarmament campaign that followed the Murle-Nuer clashes, called [[Human rights in South Sudan#Operation Restore Hope|Operation Restore Hope]]. He now claimed to be fighting for a separate state for the Murle.<ref name="SASS A-Cobra Faction">{{cite web|url=http://www.smallarmssurveysudan.org/de/facts-figures/south-sudan/armed-groups/southern-dissident-militias/ssdma-cobra-faction.html|title=SSDM/A-Cobra faction|date=15 March 2016|publisher=|accessdate=13 May 2016}}</ref> During the Civil War in January 2014, the government signed a peace agreement called the Greater Pibor Administrative Area peace agreement with the Cobra Faction which created in May that year the semi-autonomous area called the [[Greater Pibor Administrative Area]] (GPAA) to increase the minority populations within its borders and David Yau Yau was appointed chief administrator, equivalent to state governor.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.smallarmssurveysudan.org/fileadmin/docs/working-papers/HSBA-WP35-Greater-Pibor.pdf| title=Real but Fragile:The Greater Pibor Administrative Area| work=small arms survey | date=March 2015| accessdate=22 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.voanews.com/a/south-sudan-pibor-county-jonglei-/1965423.html|title=South Sudan President Gives 'Marginalized' Pibor County Special Status|publisher=Voice of America|date=25 July 2014|accessdate=14 July 2016}}</ref> Not all Cobra faction general were satisfied and a splinter group called the [[South Sudan Democratic Movement#SSDM/A - Cobra Faction|Greater Pibor Forces]] formed alleging that the SPLM were inciting the Murle to attack the Lou Nuer as a form of divide and rule. Further, on Christmas Eve 2015, Salvar Kiir announced an increase in the number of [[States of South Sudan|state]]s from 10 to 28 and then, five days later, swore in all new governors appointed by him.<ref name=foreignpolicy1>{{cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2016/01/22/south-sudan-next-civil-war-is-starting-shilluk-army/|title=South Sudan's next civil war is starting|publisher=foreignpolicy.com|accessdate=23 January 2016|date=22 January 2016}}</ref> The new borders give Kiir's Dinkas a majority in strategic locations.<ref name=foreignpolicy1/> This replaced the GPAA with [[Boma State]] and replaced Yau Yau with [[Baba Medan Konya]], angering the Cobra faction. In September 2016, the Cobra faction, now led by Khalid Boutros declared war against the government<ref name="voa2"/> but in March 2017, Boutros dissolved the faction to incorporate it into the broader faction of the National Salvation Front led by Thomas Cirillo.<ref name=tamazuj0317>{{cite news|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/ssdm-cobra-faction-dissolved-merged-cirillos-rebels|title=SSDM-Cobra Faction dissolved, merged with Cirillo's rebels|date=9 March 2017|access-date=9 March 2017|work=Radio Tamazuj}}</ref>
===Jonglei-Boma conflict=== Cattle raids between Dinka from the Dinka majority [[Jonglei|Jonglei state]] and the Murle from the Murle majority [[Boma State]] led to a peace agreement between both states on 5 December 2016 and to the formation of a joint police force recruited from the states of Jonglei, Boma and [[Eastern Bieh|Bieh]]. However attacks across states continued.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article61174|title=21 killed, 5 children abducted in Jonglei state: officials|date=20 December 2016|access-date=12 March 2017|work=Sudan Tribune}}</ref> In March, armed youth and soldiers from Jonglei state attacked and captured Kotchar, in Boma state.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/boma-deputy-governor-says-gunmen-jonglei-captured-kotchar|title=Boma deputy governor says gunmen from Jonglei captured Kotchar|date=8 March 2017|access-date=12 March 2017|work=Radio Tamazuj}}</ref> Boma state officials, as well as Khalid Boutros of the Cobra faction, accuse the SPLA of supporting the attacks on Boma state.<ref name=tamazuj0317/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/gunmen-attack-boma-villages-displaced-residents-official|title=Gunmen attack on Boma villages displaced residents: Official|date=8 March 2017|access-date=12 March 2017|work=Radio Tamazuj}}</ref> In November 2017, Murle gunmen attacked a Dinka village of Duk Payuel county in Jonglei, killing 45 people and abducting about 60 women and children.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://reliefweb.int/report/south-sudan/horrific-killing-innocent-civilians-south-sudan-condemned-un-special|title="Horrific killing of innocent civilians" in South Sudan condemned by UN Special Representative|date=29 November 2017|access-date=1 December 2017|work=Relief Web}}</ref>
== Shilluk-Dinka fighting ==
===Shilluk disarmament campaign (2010)=== Many from the [[Shilluk people]] contend that the Dinka as well as the Dinka and Nuer soldiers from the [[Sudan People's Liberation Army]] committed abuses in an attempt to disarm them in the summer of 2010. The SPLA burned scores of villages, raped hundreds of women and girls and killed an untold number of civilians in the [[Shilluk Kingdom]].<ref name=aljazeera/> Over 10,000 people were displaced in the midst of the rainy season and sent fleeing into the forest, often naked, without bedding, shelter or food, with many children dying from hunger and cold. Civilians alleging [[torture]] by the SPLA claim fingernails being torn out, burning plastic bags dripped on children to make their parents hand over weapons and villagers burned alive in their huts if rebels were suspected of spending the night there. The [[United Nations Human Rights Council]] reported many of these violations, and the frustrated director of one [[Juba]]-based international aid agency called them "human rights abuses off the [[Richter scale]]".<ref name=aljazeera/>
===Agwelek Forces, Tiger Faction New Forces and Democratic Change rebellions=== {{See also|Tiger Faction New Forces}} [[John Uliny]] from the Shilluk people lead the [[South Sudan Democratic Movement#SSDM/A-Upper Nile faction|Upper Nile faction]] of the South Sudan Democratic Movement in rebellion. In March 2011, in clashes between the Uliny's Upper Nile faction and the SPLA North of Malakal, the SSDM claimed that the SPLA killed 168 civilians and named six villages that the SPLA burned down.<ref name=Tribune7M>{{cite news|last=Tribune |first=Sudan |title=South Sudan army clashes with rebel group, over 100 dead |url=http://www.sudantribune.com/South-Sudan-army-clashes-with,38227 |accessdate=5 January 2012 |newspaper=Sudan Tribune |date=8 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111129145059/https://www.sudantribune.com/South-Sudan-army-clashes-with,38227 |archivedate=29 November 2011 }}</ref> [[Human Rights Watch]] later confirmed that over 60 ethnic Shilluk were killed, and more than 7,000 displaced. The official [[United Nations]] report counted 62 dead, 70 injured and 7,625 displaced, but how many people were actually killed is unknown.<ref name=HRW>{{cite news|last=HRW|first=WN|title=Southern Sudan: Abuses on Both Sides in Upper Nile Clashes|url=http://article.wn.com/view/2011/04/20/Southern_Sudan_Abuses_on_Both_Sides_in_Upper_Nile_Clashes/|accessdate=5 January 2012|newspaper=World News|date=19 April 2011}}</ref> During the civil war, in February 2016, 18 people were killed, including two [[Médecins Sans Frontières]] staff, in fighting between Shilluk and Dinka youths at a "protection of civilian" (POC) site, which are often divided by ethnic groups to prevent fighting.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Dumo|first1=Denis|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-southsudan-unrest-idUSKCN0VR1FU?feedType=RSS&feedName=worldNews|title=Fighting at U.N. compound in South Sudan kills 18: MSF|date=19 Feb 2016}}</ref>
Uliny entered into peace talks and accepted an amnesty by the government in 2013. However, during the civil war, after Kiir's floated the idea of carving new states which would give Kiir's Dinkas strong majorities and which the Shilluk felt would carve up their homeland, Uliny switched sides to fight with SPLO-IO in April 2015.<ref name=foreignpolicy1/> His forces were now known as the "Agwelek" army. On 16 May 2015, the Agwelek forces and elements of the SPLM-IO captured Upper Nile's capital, [[Malakal]], as well as Anakdiar and areas around [[Fashoda]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/s-sudan-rebels-johnson-olony-our-side|title=S Sudan rebels: Johnson Olony is on our side|publisher=radiotamazuj.org|accessdate=2015-06-23|date=2015-05-17}}</ref> The group said they want to run their affairs independently from others in [[Upper Nile State]], and SPLM-IO backed away from claims that it is in charge of Olony's group and stated that Olony's interests simply coincides with theirs.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/machar-backs-away-claim-loyalty-independent-shilluk-forces|title=Machar backs away from claim to loyalty of 'independent' Shilluk forces|publisher=radiotamazuj.org|accessdate=2015-06-23|date=2015-05-18}}</ref> SPLM-IO said they understood the feeling from the [[Shilluk people|Shilluk]] community that they wanted a level of independence and that that was the reason the SPLM-IO last year created Fashoda state for the Shilluk kingdom and appointed Tijwog Aguet, a Shilluk, as governor.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article55014|title=Johnson Olony's forces prefer independent command in Upper Nile state|publisher=sudantribune.com|accessdate=2015-06-23|date=2015-05-17}}</ref>
As the predominantly Shilluk Agwelek forces joined, in July 2016, with the SPLM-IO, which entered the peace agreement with the government, some Shilluk felt dissatisfied. After the establishment of the new states, a new group made up of mostly Shilluk formed the "Tiger Faction New Forces" (TFNF), led by General Yoanes Okij, alleging that the new states gives power over Shilluk lands to the Dinka.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article56894|title=New rebel group formed in South Sudan against the creation of 28 states|publisher=Sudan Tribune|accessdate=15 December 2016|date=30 October 2015}}</ref> They rejected joining the SPLM-IO or the peace agreement and called for the restoration of the original 1956 borders of the Shilluk territories.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?iframe&page=imprimable&id_article=58273|title=Tiger faction of ethnic Shilluk kingdom dismisses integration into SPLM-IO|publisher=Sudan Tribune|accessdate=15 December 2016|date=11 March 2016}}</ref> In September 2016, Shilluk politician [[Lam Akol]], leader of the largest opposition party, [[Democratic Change (South Sudan)|Democratic Change]], announced a new faction called the National Democratic Movement (NDM) to overthrow Kiir.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/lam-akol-forms-rebel-movement-fight-south-sudan-government|title=Lam Akol forms rebel movement to fight South Sudan government|date=27 September 2016|publisher=Radio Tamazuj}}</ref> Yohanis Okiech then joined the predominantly Shilluk NDM<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article61355|title=S.Sudan rebel commander says rivalry undermines struggle|date=10 January 2017|publisher=Sudan Tribune}}</ref> as deputy chief of general staff. In January 2017, Olony's forces working for SPLM-IO ambushed and killed Yohanis Okiech.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article61329|title=Another rebel commander shot dead in war-torn South Sudan|date=7 January 2017|publisher=Sudan Tribune}}</ref>
In the Upper Nile region, much of the [[South Sudanese Civil War#Renewed conflict and rebel infighting|fighting in 2016-17]] was between the SPLA and the SPLA-IO allied Upper Nile faction of Uliny. During this fighting, Shilluk in [[Wau Shilluk]] were forced from their homes and Yasmin Sooka, chairwoman of the Commission on Human Rights in South Sudan, claimed that the government was engaging in "social engineering" after it transported 2,000 mostly Dinka people to the abandoned areas.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-03-15/un-warns-of-south-sudan-27social-engineering27/8354958|title=South Sudan: UN warns of 'social engineering' amid looming threat of genocide|publisher=ABC news|accessdate=17 March 2017|date=14 March 2017}}</ref> The king of the [[Shilluk Kingdom]], Kwongo Dak Padiet, claimed his people were at risk of physical and cultural extinction.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.startribune.com/south-sudan-experiencing-ethnic-cleansing-un-report-says/415571874/|title=South Sudan experiencing ethnic cleansing, UN report says|publisher=Star Tribune|accessdate=9 March 2017|date=7 March 2017}}</ref> He claimed the SPLA razed down several villages and that his lawyers were preparing a case before the International Criminal Court against senior SPLA staff and members of the Jieng Council of Elders.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/shilluk-king-accuses-government-ethnic-cleansing-upper-nile|title=South Sudan experiencing ethnic cleansing, UN report says|publisher=Star Tribune|accessdate=9 March 2017|date=7 March 2017}}</ref>
==Fertit-Jur-Dinka fighting==
===Second Sudanese Civil War=== {{See also|1998 Sudan famine}} During the Second Sudanese Civil War, many from the [[Fertit]], which refers to the various [[Bantu people|Bantu]] groups in the Bahr el Ghazal region such as the [[Banda people|Banda]] and [[Binga people|Binga]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/reports/1999/sudan/SUDAWEB2-69.htm|title=Famine in Sudan, 1998|date=14 December 1998|publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]]}}</ref> fought on behalf of the central government in Khartoum against the SPLA.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2016/12/wau-displaced-death-horrifying-escapes-161220103833871.html|title=Wau displaced tell of death and horrifying escapes|publisher=aljazeera|accessdate=23 December 2016|date=21 December 2016}}</ref> Fertit militias often attacked Dinka civilians, with the police force in Wau, composed of Dinkas, fighting for the Dinka.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/reports/1999/sudan/SUDAWEB2-12.htm#P539_62807|title=Famine in Sudan, 1998|date=14 December 1998|publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]]}}</ref>
Another group traditionally inhabiting the Bahr El Ghazal are the Jur people. In March 2011, a clash between Dinka pastoralists of [[Lakes (state)|Lakes State]]<ref>{{cite news|title=WES's Mvolo and Lake's state Yirol West reconciliation|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/South-Sudan-WES-s-Mvolo-and-Lake-s,40192|accessdate=5 December 2016|newspaper=Sudan Tribune|date=19 September 2011}}</ref> and [[Jur Modo people|Jur]] farmers from [[Western Equatoria]] over land issues left 7 people dead and 5 injured. This happened following a similar clash over pasture that killed 10 people the previous month.<ref>{{cite news|last=Mayom|first=Manyang|title=7 Killed as Yirol West and Mvolo Clashes Ends in Sudan|url=http://www.oyetimes.com/news/africa/10117-7-killed-as-yirol-west-and-mvolo-clashes-ends-in-sudan|accessdate=5 January 2012|newspaper=Oye! Times|date=16 March 2011}}</ref> The two communities signed a memorandum of understanding in September 2011.
===South Sudanese Civil War=== {{See also|2016–17 Wau clashes}} In 2016, about a year after the Compromise Peace Agreement was signed, groups of ethnic Dinka youth and the SPLA targeted members of the [[Dār Fertit|Fertit]] in [[Wau, South Sudan|Wau]], killing dozens and forcing more than 120,000 to flee their homes.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/07/south-sudan-dozens-killed-violence-flares-wau-160703063621236.html|title=South Sudan: Dozens killed as violence flares in Wau|publisher=aljazeera|accessdate=4 July 2016|date=3 July 2016}}</ref>
In April 2017, [[Mathiang Anyoor]] led by General Thayip Gatluak<ref name=fox0417/> attacked Wau, targeting Jur and Fertit people, killing at least 18 people.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/04/south-sudan-civilians-killed-wau-fighting-170410182833372.html|title=South Sudan: Civilians killed in Wau fighting|publisher=aljazeera|accessdate=15 April 2017|date=10 April 2017}}</ref>
==Equatorian-Dinka fighting==
===South Sudanese Civil War=== {{See also|Arrow Boys}} After the [[South Sudanese Civil War#Compromise Peace Agreement|Compromise Peace Agreement]], some observers felt that the government was holding on to the peace deal to maintain international aid while backing campaigns to increase Dinka control over land and resources traditionally held by other groups. In Western Equatoria, after Dinka cattle herders, allegedly backed by the SPLA, occupied farmland, [[Azande people|Zande]] youth rose up into armed groups, notably the [[Arrow Boys]].<ref name=guardian1215>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2015/dec/07/south-sudan-horrific-attacks-prompt-communities-take-arms|title=Horrific attacks prompt South Sudan's communities to form armed groups|publisher=the guardian|accessdate=7 July 2016|date=7 December 2015}}</ref> A new rebel faction calling itself the [[South Sudan Federal Democratic Party]] (different from but related to the larger similarly named rebel faction led by [[Peter Gadet]], Gabriel Chang and Gathoth Gatkuoth), made up mostly of [[Lotuko people]] formed during this time due to growing perceptions of mistreatment by the "Dinka" government and took over a SPLA outpost in Eastern Equatoria.<ref name=ICG>{{cite web|url=https://www.crisisgroup.org/africa/horn-africa/south-sudan/south-sudan-s-south-conflict-equatorias|title=South Sudan's South:Conflict in the Equatorias|publisher=[[International Crisis Group]]|accessdate=9 January 2016|date=25 May 2016}}</ref>
For most of the [[South Sudanese Civil War]], the fighting was focused in the [[Greater Upper Nile]] region. After the clashes in Juba in 2016, the fighting spread to the previously safe haven of [[Equatoria]], where the bulk of SPLM-IO forces went for shelter.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irinnews.org/analysis/2016/11/14/who-can-stop-threat-genocide-south-sudan|title=Who can stop the threat of genocide in South Sudan?|date=14 November 2016|publisher=irinnews.org}}</ref> Accounts point to both sides targeting civilians on ethnic lines between the Dinka and the dozens of ethnic groups among the Equatorians who are historically in conflict with the Dinka, such as the Karo, who include the [[Bari people|Bari]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-southsudan-congo-refugees-idUSKBN13Q50M|title=South Sudanese flee as country edges closer to 'genocide'|date=1 December 2016|publisher=reuters}}</ref> Witnesses report Dinka soldiers threatening villagers that they will kill all [[Kakwa people|Kakwa]], another Karo people, for their alleged support to Machar and killing [[Pojulu people]] while sparing those who they find can speak [[Dinka language|Dinka]].<ref name=Reuters1216/> Much of the atrocities in around Yei are blamed on [[Mathiang Anyoor]].<ref name=bbcnews0317/> A UN investigation said rape was being used a tool of ethnic cleansing<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/united-nations-says-rape-used-as-tool-for-ethnic-cleansing-in-south-sudan/|title=UN:Rape used as a tool of ethnic cleansing in South Sudan|date=2 December 2016|publisher=CBS news}}</ref> and [[Adama Dieng]], the U.N.'s Special Adviser on the Prevention of Genocide, warned of [[genocide]] after visiting areas of fighting in [[Yei River State|Yei]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-southsudan-uganda-refugees-idUSKBN1441QU|title=Hatred spills beyond South Sudan along with refugees|date=15 December 2016|publisher=Reuters}}</ref> On 4 April 2017, a pro-government militia reportedly led by Major Gen. Gildo Oling attacked mostly [[Acholi people|Acholi]]s<ref>{{cite news|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/news/article/ndm-condemns-targeted-killings-in-wau-town|title= NDM condemns targeted killings in Wau town|date=13 April 2017|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=Radio Tamazuj}}</ref> in [[Pajok]] and SPLA-IO claimed 200 civilians were killed.<ref name=fox0417>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2017/04/13/south-sudans-silent-slaughter-dinka-massacre-unchecked-by-regional-international-groups.html|title=South Sudan's silent slaughter: Dinka massacre unchecked by regional, international groups|date=13 April 2017|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=Fox News}}</ref>
Many of the self-defense factions formed among the Equatorians have targeted Dinka civilians,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irinnews.org/analysis/2016/11/14/who-can-stop-threat-genocide-south-sudan|title=Who can stop the threat of genocide in South Sudan?|date=14 November 2016|accessdate=12 March 2017|work=IRIN news}}</ref> including in one case where a convoy of commercial vehicles along the Juba-Yei road was stopped and separated into Dinka and non-Dinka and the Dinka were executed, with up to 21 people killed.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/dinka-council-elders-condemns-juba-yei-ambush-attack|title=Dinka Council of Elders condemns Juba- Yei ambush attack|date=10 October 2016|accessdate=12 March 2017|work=Radio Tamazuj}}</ref> Among the refugees fleeing the violence are a few Dinkas as well and they faced violence among Equatorians in the refugee camps as retribution.<ref name=Reuters1216>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/africa/us-seeks-sanctions-on-south-sudan-rebel-leader-army-chief/2016/11/18/95a75fd4-ae11-11e6-8f19-21a1c65d2043_story.html|title=US seeks sanctions on South Sudan rebel leader, army chief|date=19 November 2016|publisher=washington post}}</ref> Ugandan authorities often house Dinka refugees separately to minimize violence.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irinnews.org/special-report/2017/07/12/war-equatoria|title=The war in Equatoria|date=12 July 2017|publisher=Irinnews}}</ref>
==Dinka-Arab fighting== {{See also|Abyei}} In January 2011, clashes between nomadic [[Misseriya]] [[Arab]]s and the [[Dinka]] people killed 'dozens' in Abyei preceding the independence referendum. A source of tension was reportedly the delay in holding a separate referendum for the Abyei region. The Dinkas largely supported South Sudan's independence during the [[Second Sudanese Civil War]].<ref name=Timeline>{{cite news|last=IRIN|first=AllAfrica|title=Sudan: Timeline Since the Referendum|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201103190002.html|accessdate=2 January 2012|newspaper=allAfrica.com|date=18 March 2011}}</ref> In February,at a market in Abyei, three people are killed and 300 sought refuge in a United Nations ([[United Nations Mission in Sudan|UNMIS]]) mission compound.<ref name=Timeline /> In the same month, in Todach, Abyei, ten people died when armed militias stormed a police post. Southern Sudan officials reported some of the attackers were Misseriya, but claimed the attack itself was connected to a Khartoum government-sponsored militia. In March, another militia attack in an Abyei town kills 30 people, as militia burned hundreds of dwellings and close to 25,000 people flee [[Abyei (town)|the town in Abyei]], migrating south.<ref name=Timeline /> The United Nations then sent in 100 peacekeepers.<ref name=ReutersTimeline>{{cite news|last=Cutler|first=David|title=Timeline: Sudan's disputed Abyei region|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/23/us-sudan-abyei-events-idUSTRE74M2ZP20110523|accessdate=7 January 2012|newspaper=Reuters|date=23 May 2011}}</ref> The armed forces of northern and southern Sudan deployed heavy weapons to the region.<ref name=ReutersTimeline /> In April, Sudan's president, [[Omar al-Bashir]], issued a statement saying he will not accept South Sudan's independence as voted in the January referendum unless the north takes control over the oil-rich Abyei region. A draft proposal from the south claims Abyei.<ref name=ReutersTimeline /> In May, Sudan's tanks enter Abyei, in an attempt to clear out southern forces. The UN, US and UK condemn this move.<ref name=ReutersTimeline /> By the end of the month, the [[African Union]] discloses a tentative agreement is reached, establishing a preliminary 20-kilometre [[ceasefire]] line and demilitarized region in Abyei.<ref>{{cite news|last=Gettleman|first=Jeffrey|title=North and South Sudan Tentatively Agree to Demilitarize Disputed Border|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/01/world/africa/01sudan.html|accessdate=7 January 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=31 May 2011|author2=Josh Kron}}</ref> By June, the UN reports that 146,000 people had been displaced in the Abyei region, on the disputed border zone.<ref>{{cite news|last=Mazen|first=Maram|title=Sudan's Abyei Clashes Displace 113,000 People, UN Reports|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-06-17/sudan-s-abyei-clashes-displace-113-000-people-un-reports.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120723224959/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-06-17/sudan-s-abyei-clashes-displace-113-000-people-un-reports.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=23 July 2012|accessdate=7 January 2012|newspaper=BusinessWeek|date=17 June 2011}}</ref>
==Inter-Dinka fighting== In March 2011, an armed clash over a land dispute in [[Twic East County]], [[Jonglei]] between members of the Ayuel and Dachuek [[Dinka people|Dinka]], killed 22 people, including one SPLA officer.<ref>{{cite news|last=AFP |first=Khartoum |title='22 killed in south Sudan land dispute' |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/Africa/22-killed-in-south-Sudan-land-dispute/Article1-669825.aspx |accessdate=5 January 2012 |newspaper=The Hindustan Times |date=5 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021080830/http://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/Africa/22-killed-in-south-Sudan-land-dispute/Article1-669825.aspx |archivedate=21 October 2012 }}</ref>
In 2015, more than 70 people were killed in the Apuk and Aguok clans and 2,000 cattle were used as compensation for the victims.<ref>{{cite news|title=Apuk and Aguok community of Gokrial collected 2000 head of cattle to compensate their inter-clan victims|url=http://upperniletimes.net/must-read/apuk-and-aguok-community-of-gokrial-collected-2000-head-of-cattle-to-compensate-their-inter-clan-victims/|accessdate=15 June 2017|newspaper=Upper Nile Times|date=2 September 2015}}</ref> In June 2017, 38 people were killed in [[Gogrial State]] in fighting between Apuk and Aguok over border disputes.<ref>{{cite news|title=38 killed in tribal clashes in South Sudan|url=http://www.news.com.au/world/breaking-news/38-killed-in-tribal-clashes-in-south-sudan/news-story/7273194d6e0078ff85983fe4f575f0c8|accessdate=15 June 2017|newspaper=Deutsche Presse Agentur|date=5 June 2017}}</ref>
In 2017, in Malek County in the Great Lakes Region, clashes between Ruop and Pakam clans killed at least 170 according to government officials, with 342 houses burnt and 1,800 people displaced.<ref>{{cite news|title=Death toll from fighting in South Sudan's Great Lakes rises to 170|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-southsudan-fighting-casualties/death-toll-from-fighting-in-south-sudans-great-lakes-rises-to-170-idUSKBN1E60T8|accessdate=22 December 2017|newspaper=Reuters|date=12 December 2017}}</ref>
==Inter-Nuer fighting==
===Second Sudanese Civil War=== {{See also|2009 Sobat River ambush}} During the Second Sudanese Civil War, The Luo Nuer and the [[Jikany Nuer]] were in open conflict, particular around [[Nasir, South Sudan|Nasir]] in [[Nasir County]], from the SPLA split in 1994 to around the end of the war in 2004.<ref>{{cite book |ref=harv |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_5FadVkhT6kC&pg=PA288|title=Small Arms Survey 2010: Gangs, Groups, and Guns|last=Small Arms Survey|page=288|publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2010|ISBN=0-521-14684-4}}</ref>
===South Sudanese Civil War=== {{main|South Sudanese Civil War}} During the South Sudanese Civil War, the Nuer dominated [[South Sudan Liberation Army]], led by Mathew Pul Jang, sided with the government and helped take back [[Bentiu]] in December 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article49286|title=Ex-rebels issue three day ultimatum for surrender of dissident Unity state commander|date=23 December 2013|publisher=Sudan Tribune}}</ref>
The Dinka dominated SPLA recruited militias and young men from the [[Jikany Nuer]] and Bul Nuer in Unity state to take back areas held by the Nuer dominated SPLM-IO.<ref>{{cite news|last=McNeish |first=Hannah |title=South Sudan:women and girls raped as 'wages' for government-allied fighters |url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2015/sep/28/south-sudan-women-girls-raped-as-wages-for-government-allied-fighters |accessdate=13 December 2016 |newspaper=The Guardian |date=28 September 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161221084603/https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2015/sep/28/south-sudan-women-girls-raped-as-wages-for-government-allied-fighters |archivedate=21 December 2016 |df=dmy }}</ref>

[[Image:Illuminares2007.jpg|right|200px|thumb|Lantern installations at Illuminares, 2007.]] '''Illuminares''' is an annual lantern festival held every summer in John Hendry Park (also known as [[Bodies of water in Vancouver#Trout Lake|Trout Lake]] Park) in east [[Vancouver]]. In 2010, the festival moved to [[Canada Place]], but the 2012 festival returned to John Hendry Park.<ref>{{cite news|last=Werb|first=Jessica|title=Illuminares plans to return to nature|url=https://www.straight.com/article-419956/vancouver/illuminares-plans-return-nature|accessdate=20 May 2012|newspaper=The Georgia Straight|date=11 August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Illuminares Lantern Festival set to return to Trout Lake|url=https://vancouversun.com/Illuminares+Lantern+Festival+return+Trout+Lake/6343325/story.html|accessdate=20 May 2012|newspaper=The Vancouver Sun|date=22 March 2012}}</ref> The event is put on by the [[Public Dreams Society]], a group formed in 1985 to encourage community events. ''Illuminares'' is a mixture of events put on by the society, such as fire-breathers and bands, and participants bringing their own homemade lanterns. Local artists run lantern making workshops to help people make their own personalized lantern. The festival is paid for through corporate and community sponsors, government grants as well as donations from participants at the event.
While it began as a small community festival, ''Illuminares'' has quickly grown into one of the most popular events in Vancouver. About 30,000 people come to this event each year. The number of people coming to this even grows exponentially every year. Illuminares happens on the last Saturday of July each year.
Public Dreams also participates in several other events in the Greater Vancouver area. These include the [[North Shore (Greater Vancouver)|North Shore]]'s Wild Lights Lantern Festival, held in [[Edgemont Village]], and the [[Parade of the Lost Souls]], a parade through Vancouver's [[Commercial Drive]] area around Halloween.

{{Multiple issues| {{Underlinked|date=June 2015}} {{orphan|date=February 2015}} }}
'''International Conference on Mechanical Industrial & Energy Engineering''' (ICMIEE) is held in [[Bangladesh]] every alternate 2 years starting from 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.kuet.ac.bd/icmiee2014/icmiee-2014/|title=ICMIEE Official Website}}</ref> The objective of '''ICMIEE''' is to present the latest research and results of scientists and Researchers. The conference provides opportunities for different areas' delegates to exchange new ideas and applications experiences face to face to establish research relationships.
Technological development can be enhanced through continuous research. The Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Khulna University of Engineering & Technology organizes '''International Conference on Mechanical, Industrial and Energy Engineering (ICMIEE)'''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://journalseeker.researchbib.com/?action=viewJournalDetails&issn=24097365&uid=r31169|title=ICMIEE Research Bible}}</ref> It brings great opportunities for both researchers and industrial communities to meet, discuss and share their research outcomes. This helps develop a bridge among the researchers and the experts of the industry. This conference aims to provide a common platform for the participants throughout the world to exchange their views and share the ideas in the vast field of Mechanical, Industrial and Energy Engineering.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kuet.ac.bd/index.php/welcome/shownews/299|title=ICMIEE News}}</ref>
==Areas==
* Aerodynamics * Applied Mechanics * Automation, Mechatronics and Robotics * Automobile Engineering * CAD/CAM/CIM * CFD * Computational Techniques * Composite and Smart Materials * Energy Engineering and Management * Fatigue and Fracture * Fluid Mechanics and Machinery * Fuels and Combustion * Heat and Mass Transfer * IC Engines * Industrial Engineering * Instrumentation and Control * Leather Engineering * Manufacturing and Production Process * MEMS and Nanotechnology * Oil and Gas Exploration * Operations Research and Management * Pollution and Environmental Engineering * Quality Management, Quality Engineering * Refrigeration and Air-conditioning * Renewable Energy * Safety and Maintenance * Supply Chain Management * Textile Engineering * Tribology
