revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} This is intended to be a list of notable accidents that occurred during the shooting of films and television, such as cast or crew fatalities or serious accidents that plagued production. It is not intended to be a list of every minor injury an actor or stuntman suffered during filming. Stuntwork accounts for over half of all film-related injuries, with an average of five deaths for every 2,000 injuries.{{citation needed|date=September 2011}} From 1980 to 1990, there were 37 deaths relating to accidents during stunts; 24 of these deaths involved the use of helicopters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uic.edu/sph/glakes/harts1/HARTS_library/stunts.txt|title= Stunt Safety By Michael McCann, Ph.D., C.I.H.}}</ref>
==1910s== * ''Across the Border'' (1914). On July 1, 1914, while on location in [[Canon City, Colorado]], cast member Grace McHugh was filming a scene where her character was crossing the [[Arkansas River]] in a boat. When the boat capsized, camera operator Owen Carter immediately jumped into the river to save her. He dragged her onto a [[sandbar]] that was actually [[quicksand]]. The rest of the film crew watched helplessly as they were sucked into the quicksand and drowned.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=CTR19140702.2.5|title=Grace McHugh, Golden Girl, Is Drowned|author=Staff|work=([[Golden, Colorado|Golden]]) [[Golden Transcript|Colorado Transcript]]|page=1|date=July 2, 1915|accessdate=September 7, 2016}}</ref> *''[[The Birth of a Nation]]'' (1915). Future film director [[Erich von Stroheim]] fell off a roof and broke two ribs in one scene as an extra.{{Citation needed|date=July 2017}} *[[The Girl of the Golden West (1915 film)|''The Girl of the Golden West'']] (1915). Actor [[House Peters Sr.]] suffered serious burns to his face and hands when a prop pistol exploded upon being fired.<ref>Katchmer, George A. ''Eighty Silent Film Stars: Biographies and Filmographies of the Obscure to the Well Known.'' Jefferson, NC: McFarland, 1991. p-785.</ref> *[[The Captive (1915 film)|''The Captive'']] (1915). During filming of a scene where soldiers were required to break down a locked door, the extras fired at the door using live ammunition to give the scene more realism. The director then ordered the extras to reload with blanks in order to film the next shot in which the door is broken down. But one of the extras inadvertently left a live round in his rifle which discharged, shooting another extra, Charles Chandler, in the head, killing him instantly.<ref>DeMille, Cecil B., and Donald Hayne, ed. ''The Autobiography of Cecil B. DeMille''. London: W.H. Allen, 1960. p-116-117.</ref> *''[[The Woman God Forgot]]'' (1917). In one scene, extras were required to be thrown over the side of an Aztec pyramid. The 'pyramid' was built of wood and covered in paper on which sand had been glued to create the appearance of stone. The extras were 'sand-papered' as they slid down the side of the structure. Having expected such injuries, a crew member was waiting at the bottom with a bucket of iodine.<ref>Fountain, Leatrice G., and John R. Maxim ''1985: Dark Star''. London: Sidgwick & Jackson. p-189.</ref> * ''[[The Valley of the Giants (1919 film)|The Valley of the Giants]]'' (1919). Silent era star [[Wallace Reid]] was badly injured in a train crash during filming in Oregon. His injuries caused him severe pain and the studio supplied him with increasing quantities of morphine so he could keep working. Addicted to morphine and also suffering from alcoholism, Reid died in 1923 at the age of 32.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goldensilents.com/stars/wallacereid.html |title=Wallace Reid (1891-1923) |publisher=''Golden Silents'' |accessdate=6 June 2014}}</ref> *Unidentified [[Henry Lehrman]] Comedy (1919): Comedian [[Billie Ritchie]], while working on a short comedy film, was kicked in the stomach by an [[ostrich]] and sustained internal injuries.<ref>[http://www.bearmanormedia.com/index.php?route=product/product&filter_name=massa&product_id=638 Steve Massa- Lame Brains and Lunatics pp. 66-67]</ref>
==1920s== * ''[[Haunted Spooks]]'' (1920). On the set of a publicity shoot that took place while filming, actor and comedian [[Harold Lloyd]] picked up what he thought was a prop bomb with the fuse lit but realized too late the bomb was real. It detonated, blowing off the thumb and first finger of his right hand and also temporarily blinding him. For the rest of his career, Lloyd concealed his missing fingers with a prosthetic glove.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.silentfilm.org/archive/girl-shy-1924 |title=''Girl Shy'', 1924 |publisher=San Francisco Silent Film Festival |accessdate=6 June 2014}}</ref> *''[[The Skywayman]]'' (1920). Pilots Milton Elliott and [[Ormer Locklear]] were killed on 2 August 1920, during filming. Their plane crashed at the DeMille Airfield, along Wilshire Blvd. in Los Angeles, while filming night scenes.<ref name="Farmer1984">{{cite book|last=Farmer|first=James H.|title=Broken wings: Hollywood's air crashes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vAMIAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=4 May 2012|year=1984|publisher=Pictorial Histories Pub. Co.|isbn=978-0-933126-46-6|page=108}}</ref> *[[Manslaughter (1922 film)|''Manslaughter'']] (1922). Stunt man Leo Noomis was required to crash a police motorcycle into the side of a car at 45 miles per hour. Noomis suffered six broken ribs and a fractured pelvis while performing the stunt.<ref>Wise, Arthur, and Derek Ware. ''Stunting in the Cinema''. London: Constable, 1973. p-43.</ref> * ''[[Souls for Sale]]'' (1923). Actress [[Barbara La Marr]] injured her ankle during filming and doctors prescribed not only morphine but also cocaine to control the pain and enable her to continue filming. Working on the production left La Marr addicted to drugs, a factor that contributed to her premature death three years later.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://barbaralamarr.com/Page_2.html |title=Barbara La Marr Biography |author=Lore, Anne |accessdate=7 June 2014}}</ref> *''[[Sherlock, Jr.]]'' (1924). While hanging from a water tower, [[Buster Keaton]] pulled a rope that released water from the tower, knocking him to the ground. In the scene, he stood and ran into the distance. During a routine physical examination 11 years later, an X-ray revealed that Keaton's neck had been fractured.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.silentfilm.org/pages/detail/3691|title=Sherlock Jr., 1924|work=Silent Film Festival|last=Johansson|first=David|accessdate=1 December 2013}}</ref> *''[[The Warrens of Virginia (1924 film)|The Warrens of Virginia]]'' (1924). On 29 November 1923, while working on location in [[San Antonio, Texas]], [[Martha Mansfield]] was severely burned when a match, tossed by a cast member, ignited her [[American Civil War|Civil War]] costume of [[Hoop skirt|hoopskirts]] and flimsy ruffles. Mansfield was playing the role of Agatha Warren and had just finished her scenes and retired to a car when her clothing burst into flames. Her neck and face were saved when leading man Wilfred Lytell threw his heavy [[overcoat]] over her. The [[chauffeur]] of Mansfield's car was burned badly on his hands while trying to remove the burning clothing from the actress. The fire was put out, but she sustained substantial burns to her body and died the following day.<ref>''[[New York Times]]'', "Martha Mansfield, Film Star, Dies of Burns Caused by Costume Fired by Smoker's Match", 1 December 1923, Page 1.</ref> *''[[Ben-Hur (1925 film)|Ben-Hur]]'' (1925). An early filming attempt of the chariot race was done on location at the [[Circus Maximus]] in Rome. It brought about the death of one stuntman when a wheel of his chariot broke.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Parade's Gone By...|last=Brownlow|first=Kevin|authorlink=Kevin Brownlow|year=1969}} quoted in {{cite web|url=http://www.snopes.com/movies/films/benhur.asp|title=Ben-Hur|work=snopes.com|last=Johnson|first=Judy|accessdate=20 August 2012}}</ref> * [[The General (1926 film)|''The General'']] (1926). During filming of the epic comedy in Oregon, there were a number of incidents. Several National Guardsmen, employed as extras for the Civil War battle scenes, were injured by mishaps caused by misfired muskets or explosions. Director and star Buster Keaton was knocked unconscious when he stood too close to a cannon firing. Assistant director Harry Barnes was accidentally hit in the face by a blank charge. Train brakeman Fred Lowry sued the production for US$2,900 after his foot was crushed when it was run over by a locomotive wheel during filming of one of the railway scenes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.angelfire.com/indie/busterkeaton/Filming.html |title=The Filming of ''The General'' |publisher=Angelfire.com |accessdate=19 June 2014}}</ref> *''[[Wings (1927 film)|Wings]]'' (1927). During filming of the World War I aerial combat scenes, stunt pilot [[Dick Grace]] was required to deliberately crash-land a [[Fokker D-VII]], specially modified to "crumple" on impact. When the Fokker struck the ground, the landing gear failed to crumple, making the impact a heavier one than planned. This caused Grace's safety straps to break, sending his head through the instrument panel, leaving him with four crushed vertebrae and a broken neck. Amazingly, Grace spent only six weeks in the hospital and was back performing stunt work within a year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.silentsaregolden.com/articles/aviationstuntmen.html |title=Daredevils in the Air: Three of the Greats – Wilson, Locklear and Grace |author=Lussier, Tim |publisher=''Silents Are Golden'' |date=2004 |accessdate=6 June 2014}}</ref> * ''[[Noah's Ark (1928 film)|Noah's Ark]]'' (1928). Three people died, one man lost a leg and a number were injured in a scene where several hundred extras were caught in the "[[Genesis flood narrative|Great Flood]]." The deaths were instrumental in the introduction of film safety regulations the following year.<ref>{{cite book |author=Baxter, John O. |title=Stunt; the story of the great movie stunt men |publisher=Doubleday |location=Garden City, N.Y |year=1974 |pages= |isbn=0-385-06520-5}}</ref> * [[The Aviator (1929 film)|''The Aviator'']] (1929). During aerial scouting for locations, an aircraft crashed, killing cameraman Alvin Knechtel and actor and stunt pilot [[William Hauber]].<ref name="Yahoo">{{cite web |url=https://tv.yahoo.com/news/safety-set-camera-crew-outnumber-stunt-personnel-4-165559917.html |title=Safety On Set: Camera Crew Outnumber Stunt Personnel 4-To-1 In On-Set Deaths |author=Robb, David |publisher=[[Yahoo!]] |date=8 April 2014 |accessdate=19 June 2014}}</ref> *''[[The Godless Girl]]'' (1929). The filming of one scene required cast members [[Lina Basquette]] and [[George Duryea]] to be trapped in a burning building and both actors had their clothing, hair and exposed skin covered with an asbestos coating. During filming, Duryea, concerned that the pyrotechnic flames were getting too hot and too close, fled from the set but Basquette, eager to impress director [[Cecil B DeMille]], insisted on remaining until the scene was completed despite the intense heat. The actress suffered serious burns and blistering to her forearms and her eyebrows and lashes were singed.<ref>Basquette, Lina. ''Lina: DeMille's Godless Girl''. Fairfax, VA: Denlinger's Publishers, 1990. p-116-117.</ref> * Unknown film (1929). [[Strongheart]], the [[German Shepherd]] film star, was accidentally burned after coming into contact with a hot studio light. The burn became tumorous, eventually leading to his death later that year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.walkoffame.com/strongheart |title=Strongheart |publisher=[[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] |accessdate=10 July 2015}}</ref>
==1930s== *''[[Hell's Angels (film)|Hell's Angels]]'' (1930). Three pilots were killed during the filming.<ref name="Flying Magazine">{{cite book|title=Flying Magazine|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZwxbHfALeX0C&pg=PA77|accessdate=4 May 2012|date=April 2006|page=77|issn=0015-4806}}</ref> The sole [[Sikorsky S-29-A]], owned by [[Roscoe Turner]], which portrayed a German [[Gothaer Waggonfabrik|Gotha]] bomber, crashed during filming on 22 March 1929 when stunt pilot Al Wilson put it in a spin for its final scene and was unable to recover. He was ready to bail out and called back to his mechanic Phil Jones (who was in the rear of the plane dumping lampblack to simulate smoke) to jump, but he didn't hear him and went down with the plane. Only one brief shot of the spinning Sikorsky was used in the film.<ref>{{cite book|title=St. Louis Aviation|author=Jeremy R. C. Cox, St Louis Air and Space Museum}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Celluloid Wings|author1=James H. Farmer |author2=Tab Books Inc. }}</ref> * ''[[Such Men Are Dangerous]]'' (1930). During aerial filming off the coast of Southern California near Santa Monica on 2 January 1930, two [[Stinson Detroiter]] aircraft, employed as camera-planes, collided over the ocean. All ten men on board the two planes were killed, including director [[Kenneth Hawks]] (brother of [[Howard Hawks]]), assistant-director Max Gold, cinematographer [[Conrad Wells]], director of photography George Eastman, cameramen Otto Jordan and Ben Frankel, two property men and both pilots. Only five bodies were recovered. As it was one of the final scenes to be filmed, the movie was still completed on schedule. Families of the men who were lost took legal action against Fox Film Company but the courts ruled in favour of the latter.<ref name="Yahoo"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://scocal.stanford.edu/opinion/parker-v-james-granger-inc-24868 |title=Parker vs. James Granger, Inc. |publisher=[[Stanford University]] |accessdate=4 June 2014}}</ref><ref name="Deadline Hollywood">{{cite web |url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/04/movies-tv-on-set-deaths-camera-crews-stunts/ |title=Safety On Set: Camera Crew Outnumber Stunt Personnel 4-To-1 In On-Set Deaths |author=Robb, David |publisher=''Deadline Hollywood'' |date=8 April 2014 |accessdate=4 June 2014}}</ref> * [[The Viking (1931 film)|''The Viking'']] (1931). After completion of filming in Canada, producer, co-director and real-life adventurer [[Varick Frissell]] decided that more footage of the [[Labrador]] ice floes was required. He and a small film crew joined the real ship ''The Viking'' on a seal-hunting voyage in order to obtain the footage he wanted. On 15 March, the ship became trapped in ice near [[Horse Islands (Newfoundland and Labrador)|Horse Isles]] and dynamite stored on board (intended for breaking up ice floes) accidentally detonated, destroying the vessel and killing 27 men, including Frissell and cameraman Alexander Penrod.<ref name="Yahoo"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tcm.com/this-month/article/466486%7C465795/The-Viking.html |title=''The Viking'' |publisher=[[Turner Classic Movies]] |accessdate=4 June 2014}}</ref> * ''[[Four Frightened People]]'' (1934). During filming in Hawaii, actress [[Claudette Colbert]] was required to stand up to her neck in a real swamp. This scene was shot on her first day on set after having undergone an emergency appendectomy and Colbert and the director disregarded concerns raised by the on-set nurse. Filming in the unsanitary conditions while not yet fully recovered led to Colbert being hospitalized with a severe fever two days later.<ref>Quirk, Lawrence J. ''Claudette Colbert: An Illustrated Biography''. New York: Crown, 1985.p-62.</ref> * [[The Lost Patrol (1934 film)|''The Lost Patrol'']] (1934). During filming in high temperatures in Buttercup Valley near [[Yuma, Arizona]], Director [[John Ford]] insisted his cast and crew only work in the early mornings and late afternoons to avoid the most intense heat of each day. Under pressure from RKO to speed up filming, Producer [[Cliff Reid]] insisted that the midday break be shortened. Ford refused, believing that many of the crew would be at risk of heatstroke in the 120-degree [[Fahrenheit|F]] conditions. Reid tried to prove his point by walking around in the open in the midday heat and soon collapsed with heat exhaustion, requiring hospital treatment.<ref>Nollen, Scott Allen. ''Three Bad Men: John Ford, John Wayne, Ward Bond''. Performing Arts Publishing, 2013. P-56.</ref> *[[The Crusades (film)|''The Crusades'']] (1935). While filming a battle scene in which horses fall into a moat, four stunt riders sustained serious injuries which required hospitalization. All four of their horses were injured so severely they had to be destroyed. It was recommended that the injured stunt-men receive extra pay but director [[Cecil B DeMille]] refused, saying that the riders had 'bungled a simple scene'.<ref>Cary, Diana S. ''The Hollywood Posse: The Story of a Gallant Band of Horsemen who Made Movie History.'' Boston: Houghton Mifflin, 1975. p-223-224.</ref> *''[[The Charge of the Light Brigade (1936 film)|The Charge of the Light Brigade]]'' (1936). During the filming of the charge sequence, a stuntman was killed when he fell off his horse and landed on a broken sword that was lying on the field, unfortunately wedged in such a position that its blade was sticking straight up. Also, due to the use of trip wires, three dozen horses had their legs broken and had to be shot during filming, resulting in the U.S. Congress passing laws to protect animals used in motion pictures.{{Citation needed|date=July 2012}} *''[[Saratoga (film)|Saratoga]]'' (1937). [[Lionel Barrymore]] broke his hip after tripping on a cable on the set that film.<ref>{{cite web|last=Haun|first=Harry|title=NOISES OFF-BROADWAY AND BEYOND: ''The Old Man and the Moon'' Shines Bright and High Kicks Fill the ''Can-Can''|date=30 September 2014|publisher=''[[Playbill]]''|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/noises-off-broadway-and-beyond-the-old-man-and-the-moon-shines-bright-and-high-kicks-fill-the-can-can-com-331840|accessdate=1 September 2018}}</ref> *''[[Jesse James (1939 film)|Jesse James]]'' (1939). A horse was killed during the scene where it was ridden off a cliff into a river. This incident led to the [[American Humane Association]] opening a Hollywood office in 1940 and monitoring the treatment of animals in films.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/18071/Jesse-James/articles.html|title=Jesse James|author=Jeremy Arnold|website=tcm.com|publisher=Turner Classic Movies|accessdate=3 February 2015}}</ref> * ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz]]'' (1939). [[Margaret Hamilton (actress)|Margaret Hamilton]] was badly burned during a scene in which her character, the [[Wicked Witch of the West]], "vanished" in a burst of flame and smoke. A delay in activating a trap door left her exposed to the pyrotechnic device.<ref name="Huffington">{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/04/11/freak-accidents-movie-sets_n_1417983.html |title=13 Freak Accidents On Film Sets: Brandon Lee, Nicole Kidman And Other Celebs (PHOTOS) |author=Gates, Sara |work=[[HuffPost]] |date=13 April 2012 |accessdate=10 April 2013}}</ref> Her [[stunt double]] was also injured in a scene involving a smoking broomstick.<ref>Harmetz, A. (1998). ''The Making of the Wizard of Oz: Movie Magic and Studio Power in the Prime of MGM.'' New York: Hyperion Books.</ref> [[Buddy Ebsen]] suffered a severe allergic reaction to his [[Tin Woodman|Tin Man]] makeup that resulted in a collapsed lung and lifelong breathing issues.<ref>Cox, Stephen (1988, rev. 2003). ''The Beverly Hillbillies: A Fortieth Anniversary Wing Ding''. Cumberland House Publishing; Rev Exp edition. {{ISBN|1-58182-302-9}}.</ref> He was unable to continue working on the production and was replaced by [[Jack Haley]]. *[[Hotel Imperial (1939 film)|''Hotel Imperial'']] (1939). Actor [[Ray Milland]] was seriously injured while filming a cavalry charge scene through a small village. While making a planned jump over an obstacle, the horse's saddle came loose and Milland fell into a pile of masonry. He spent a week in hospital with concussion, a 3-inch gash to his forehead and a badly injured left hand.<ref>Milland, Ray. ''Wide Eyed in Babylon''. New York: Morrow. 1974. p-189.</ref>
==1940s== *''[[Citizen Kane]]'' (1941). While filming, [[Orson Welles]] tripped down a staircase and chipped his anklebone, forcing him to use a wheelchair for the next two weeks. Welles also injured his hand during a scene where he destroyed a room.<ref name="Rosen">{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/12/03/leonardo-dicaprio-django-unchained-hand-injury_n_2230839.html|title=Leonardo DiCaprio's 'Django Unchained' Role Led To Hand Injury|author=Rosen, Christopher|date=3 December 2012|work=[[HuffPost]]|accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref> *''[[My Life for Ireland]]'' (1941). An anti-British propaganda film made by the Germans. During the epic final battle scene, several extras were killed when one of them stepped on a live land mine. The footage is said to have been included in the release prints, although no proof of this has been established.{{Citation needed|date=July 2012}} *''[[They Died with Their Boots On]]'' (1941). Three horsemen perished during the cavalry charge, one of whom was extra Jack Budlong, whose horse tripped as he rode alongside [[Errol Flynn]]. As he fell forward, he had the foresight to toss his sword ahead of him. Unfortunately, it landed handle down and stuck in place. Budlong was impaled on his own sword, and died in a Los Angeles hospital a few hours later.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/92817/They-Died-with-Their-Boots-On/articles.html|title=They Died with Their Boots On (1942) - Articles - TCM.com|website=Turner Classic Movies}}</ref> * ''[[Reap the Wild Wind]]'' (1942). According to a biographer, actor [[John Wayne]] suffered a chronic inner-ear condition for the rest of his life after filming under-water scenes in this production.<ref>Davis, Ronald L. ''Duke: The Life and Image of John Wayne''. Norman: University of Oklahoma Press, 1998. p-101.</ref> * ''Signed with Their Honour'' (unfinished, 1943). This was to have been a British war film based on the 1942 novel of the same name by [[James Aldridge]]. But during filming in [[Cheshire]], a pair of [[Gloster Gladiator|Gladiator]] biplanes collided, injuring both pilots who managed to escape by parachute. After this incident, the film project was abandoned.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rafcommands.com/archive/13973.php |title=61 OTU and the making of a Gladiator film 1943 |publisher=Royal Air Force Commands |accessdate=4 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://aviation-safety.net/wikibase/wiki.php?id=68952 |title=ASN Aircraft accident, 24-NOV-1943 Gloster Gladiator MkI K7927 |publisher=Aviation Safety Network |accessdate=4 June 2014}}</ref> * ''[[The Royal Mounted Rides Again]]'' (1945). [[Jack Randall (actor)|Addison "Jack" Randall]] was killed at [[Canoga Park]], California, while riding a horse past the cameras at full speed on July 16, 1945, for a [[Universal Pictures]] [[Serial film|serial]], when he fell from the saddle while trying to retrieve his hat which had blown off his head, and struck a tree. He died shortly thereafter.<ref>Associated Press, "Cowboy Actor - Husband Of Barbara Bennett Killed", ''The San Bernardino Daily Sun'', San Bernardino, California, Tuesday 17 July 1945, Volume 51, page 1.</ref> *''[[Unconquered]]'' (1947). During the filming of the historical adventure, nine extras suffered burns including one man who had his hair partially burnt off because director [[Cecil B DeMille]] insisted on using real fireballs and flaming arrows for one of the battle scenes.<ref>Hanson, Patricia K., and Amy Dunkleberger, eds. ''American Film Institute Catalog of Motion Pictures Produced in the United States. Feature films, 1941-1950.'' Film Entries, M-Z. Berkeley: U of California P, 1999. p-2648.</ref> In another incident, stunt woman Polly Burson was filming a scene that required a canoe to go over a waterfall. She missed the tree limb she was supposed to grab onto and fell into the safety net which was below the water's surface. Landing face down in the net, she nearly drowned and was only barely able to struggle upright in time.<ref>Wiener, David J. ''Burns, Falls, and Crashes: Interviews with Movie Stunt Performers''. Jefferson, NC: McFarland, 1996. p-29.</ref>
==1950s== *''[[The Conqueror (1956 film)|The Conqueror]]'' (1956). The exterior scenes were [[shot on location]] near [[St. George, Utah]], {{convert|137|miles|abbr=out}} downwind of the United States government's [[Nevada Test Site]]. In 1953, extensive above-ground [[nuclear weapons]] testing had occurred at the test site, as part of [[Operation Upshot–Knothole]]. Director [[Dick Powell]] died of cancer in January 1963, [[Pedro Armendáriz]] was diagnosed with kidney cancer in 1960, and committed suicide in 1963 after he learned his condition had become terminal. [[Susan Hayward]], [[John Wayne]], and [[Agnes Moorehead]] all died of cancer in the 1970s. Cast member actor [[John Hoyt]] died of lung cancer in 1991. The cast and crew totaled 220 people. By 1981, 91 of them had developed some form of cancer and 46 had died of the disease. Several of Wayne and Hayward's relatives also had cancer scares as well after visiting the set. [[Michael Wayne]] developed skin cancer, his brother [[Patrick Wayne]] had a benign tumor removed from his breast and Hayward's son Tim Barker had a benign tumor removed from his mouth. It is not clear, however, that the cancer rate for this film crew was significantly higher than in the general population. Further, while the cast members noted developed a wide variety of cancers, according to [[The New England Journal of Medicine]], [[leukemia]] is the only form of cancer known to develop from exposure to fallout radiation.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gasdetection.com/interscan-in-the-news/magazine-articles/movie-conqueror-really-cursed-look-radiation-paranoia/ |title=Was The Movie ''The Conqueror'' Really Cursed? A Look At Radiation Paranoia |author=Shaw, Michael D. |publisher=Interscan Corporation |date=14 September 2009 |accessdate=5 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |pmid=759916 |title=Childhood leukemias associated with fallout from nuclear testing |journal=New England Journal of Medicine |volume=300 |issue=8 |pages=397–402 |publisher=[[National Center for Biotechnology Information]] |date=22 February 1979 |author1=Lyon |first1=J. L |last2=Klauber |first2=M. R |last3=Gardner |first3=J. W |last4=Udall |first4=K. S |doi=10.1056/NEJM197902223000804 }}</ref> *''[[The Ten Commandments (1956 film)|The Ten Commandments]]'' (1956). [[Cecil B DeMille]] overcame a minor [[Heart attack]] while climbing down by ladder from the top of the Egyptian city gate set during filming the "take three" of the Exodus sequence. In another incident, during filming of a sand-storm scene, an extra carrying a flaming torch tripped over and the torch set fire to the clothing of a young girl standing next to him. The girl only suffered minor burns thanks to the quick thinking of make-up artist [[Frank Westmore]] who raced over and tore off her burning costume. During the filming of the same scene, several Egyptian extras were bitten by scorpions and a cobra which had been blown out of their burrows in the sand by the artificially generated storm.<ref>Westmore, Frank, and Muriel Davidson. ''The Westmores of Hollywood''. Philadelphia: J.B. Lippincott, 1976. p-159-162.</ref> *''[[Varan the Unbelievable]]'' (1958). Minor injuries, exhaustion and dehydration are common hazards for suit actors of the [[kaiju]] genre, but during the filming of 'Varan' suit actor [[Haruo Nakajima]] (who also portrayed [[Godzilla]] for 18 years) was severely burned due to a pyrotechnics mishap. This was the only time in his career that his injuries forced him to be replaced for the remainder of the shoot.<ref>Lees, J.D. and Cerasini, Marc. (1998). ''The Official Godzilla Compendium'' Random House, p. 28.</ref> *''[[Ben-Hur (1959 film)|Ben-Hur]]'' (1959). Joe Canutt, who was [[Charlton Heston]]'s stunt double, sustained a gash on his chin after being flipped out of his chariot during a chariot race scene.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/stuntman-death-in-ben-hur/ |title=Did a Stuntman Die in ''Ben Hur''? |publisher=[[Snopes.com]] |accessdate=24 May 2018}}</ref> *''[[The Horse Soldiers]]'' (1959). Fred Kennedy, a veteran stuntman and bit player, was killed in a horse fall on location in Louisiana. Director [[John Ford]] was so upset he closed the set and had to film the rest of the scene later in the [[San Fernando Valley]], and in a cut-down version.{{Citation needed|date=May 2014}}
==1960s== * [[The Alamo (1960 film)|''The Alamo'']] (1960). Actor [[Laurence Harvey]], who played Colonel [[William Travis|W B Travis]], was injured when a cannon recoiled while firing, with one of the wheels rolling over his foot, fracturing it. He did not reveal his injury until filming of the scene was completed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mysanantonio.com/entertainment/movies/article/The-Alamo-turns-50-720600.php |title=''The Alamo'' Turns 50 |author=Saldana, Hector |publisher=MySanAntonio.com |date=23 October 2010 |accessdate=21 November 2015}}</ref> * [[Spartacus (film)|''Spartacus'']] (1960). Actor [[Charles McGraw]] suffered a broken jaw on the set of the Roman epic. During the revolt at the Gladiator school, Spartacus ([[Kirk Douglas]]) is seen forcing the head of evil trainer Marcellus (McGraw) into a cauldron of soup, drowning him. McGraw's jaw struck the rim of the pot, sustaining a fracture but he managed to continue the scene nonetheless.<ref>Rode, Alan K. ''Charles McGraw: Biography of a Film Noir Tough Guy''. McFarland & Co, 2007. p187.</ref> * [[The Guns of Navarone (film)|''The Guns of Navarone'']] (1961). He insisted on returning to complete filming of his scenes before he had fully recovered, later causing a relapse of his illness that resulted in another seven weeks in hospital.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/21984/The-Guns-of-Navarone/articles.html |title=''The Guns of Navarone'' |publisher=[[Turner Classic Movies]] |accessdate=22 November 2015}}</ref> * ''[[Cape Fear (1962 film)|Cape Fear]]'' (1962). Soviet actress [[:ru:Бурдученко, Инна Георгиевна|Inna Burduchenko]] suffered third degree burns while filming in a burning [[barracks]] on 30 July 1960. She died in the hospital on 15 August. Burudchenko was three months pregnant at the time of her death.<ref>{{cite web|title=Інна Бурдученко - актриса з трагічною долею|url=http://www.gorod.cn.ua/news_8672.html|website=gorod.cn.ua|accessdate=12 July 2017|language=Russian|date=March 31, 2009}}</ref> * ''[[How the West Was Won (film)|How the West Was Won]]'' (1962). Stuntman Bob Morgan, husband of [[Yvonne De Carlo]], was seriously injured and lost a leg during a break in filming a gunfight on a moving train. Chains holding logs on a flatbed car broke, crushing Morgan as he crouched beside them.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.snopes.com/movies/films/westwon.htm|title=How the West Was Won|publisher=[[Snopes]]|accessdate=5 May 2012}}</ref> *''[[Lawrence of Arabia (film)|Lawrence of Arabia]]'' (1962). Actor [[Peter O'Toole]] was nearly killed when he fell from his camel. He also injured his hand during filming by punching through the window of a caravan while drunk. A brace or bandage can be seen on his left thumb during the first train attack scene, presumably due to this incident.{{Citation needed|date=December 2012}} *''[[The Manchurian Candidate (1962 film)|The Manchurian Candidate]]'' (1962). While filming a fight scene with [[Henry Silva]], [[Frank Sinatra]] broke his little finger during a movement where he smashed through a table. This resulted in problems with his hand for several years and is said to be one of the reasons why he pulled out of a starring role in ''[[Dirty Harry]]'', having to undertake surgery to alleviate pains.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://listverse.com/2014/06/07/10-strange-stories-about-frank-sinatra/ |title=10 Strange Stories About Frank Sinatra |author=Moore, Nolan |publisher=Listverse |date=7 June 2014 |accessdate=4 December 2017}}</ref> * ''[[The War Lover]]'' (1962). During aerial filming over the English Channel, parachutists jumped from a vintage [[B-17]] to simulate a bail-out. [[Peter Sellers]] was originally to have portrayed a fourth character, Major "King" Kong. However, Sellers injured his ankle while filming a take as Kong. As a result, [[Slim Pickens]] played the role of Kong. [[Scott Simon]] claims the titular character is in a wheelchair because of Sellers' ankle injury.<ref>{{cite web|last2=Simon|first2=Scott|last1=Garcia-Navarro|first1=Lulu|title=Classic Movie Review: 'Dr. Strangelove'|date=19 August 2017|publisher=[[NPR]]|url=https://www.npr.org/2017/08/19/544641105/classic-movie-review-dr-strangelove|accessdate=3 September 2017}}</ref> *''[[Goldfinger (film)|Goldfinger]]'' (1964). [[Harold Sakata]] burned his hand while filming the fight at Fort Knox, where his character, [[Oddjob]], gets electrocuted, but continued to act as the scene was still being filmed.<ref>{{cite news |author1=Fin Martin |author2=Antohy Evans |lastauthoramp=yes| title = Know their Roles | pages= 26–31 | work = Power Slam Magazine | id = 109 | date = August 2003 | publisher=SW Publishing LTD | location=[[Lancaster, Lancashire]], England}}</ref> *''[[The Flight of the Phoenix (1965 film)|The Flight of the Phoenix]]'' (1965). On 8 July 1965, pilot [[Paul Mantz]] crashed and was killed on a second take making a low pass.<ref name="Flying Magazine"/><ref name="HowStuffWorks">{{cite web |url=http://entertainment.howstuffworks.com/8-stars-who-died-during-the-filming-of-a-movie.htm |title=10 Stars Who Died During the Filming of a Movie |work=HowStuffWorks.com |accessdate=21 December 2012}}</ref> *''[[Lt. Robin Crusoe, U.S.N.]]'' (1965). Cameraman Robert King Baggot was killed during filming in [[Kauai]] when a huge wave hit his boat and washed him overboard.<ref name="Yahoo"/> *''[[Thunderball (film)|Thunderball]]'' (1965). While filming the scene where [[SPECTRE]] agent Angelo crashes the [[Avro Vulcan]] into the ocean near [[The Bahamas]], the stunt double for Angelo nearly drowned when the stunt double for [[Emilio Largo]] accidentally disconnected both the prop oxygen line and the double's actual oxygen line underneath.<ref name="Bahamas">''James Bond in the Bahamas'' featurette, ''[[Casino Royale (2006 film)|Casino Royale]]'' Blu-ray, 2006</ref> *''High Jungle'' (1966). A stuntman was mauled to death on camera when a shark, which was supposed to have been sedated, suddenly attacked.{{Citation needed|date=July 2012}}
==1970s== * ''[[Barquero]]'' (1970). On August 28, 1969, Director [[Robert Sparr]] was killed in a plane crash while scouting filming locations with cameraman [[Gerald Finnerman]]. The single engine plane they were riding in went down near the Brush Hollow Reservoir outside of [[Penrose, Colorado]]. The pilot was also killed in the crash, but Finnerman survived. One of the film's stars, [[Lee Van Cleef]], was scheduled to accompany Sparr and Finnerman on the scouting trip, but he backed out at the last minute.{{Citation needed|date=February 2017}} * ''[[Catch-22 (film)|Catch-22]]'' (1970). Second unit director John Jordan was killed when he was sucked out of a [[B-25 Mitchell]] while filming a bombing scene. He refused to wear a safety harness while the plane was in flight.<ref name="World's Strangest"/> * ''[[Insee thong]]'' (1970). Thai star [[Mitr Chaibancha]] was killed while starring as his popular character, the masked crime-fighter Insee Daeng (Red Eagle). On the final day of shooting, Mitr was required to grab a rope ladder hanging from a helicopter. However he only managed to grab the lowest rung. Unaware of this, the helicopter pilot took off until Mitr finally lost his grip and fell to the ground. The accident was caught on film and appeared in the final theatrical release. The fall was removed from the DVD release version.<ref>{{cite web|last=Tupchai|first=Suchada|title=Adoring fans remember famous Thai film star Mitr Chiabancha|url=http://www.pattayamail.com/586/features.shtml|publisher='Pattaya Mail.}}</ref> * ''[[Tora! Tora! Tora!]]'' (1970). Assistant-director Burch Williams (brother of producer [[Elmo Williams]]), cameraman Skeets Kelly and pilots Jim Liddy and Gilbert Chomat were all killed.<ref name="Yahoo"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://aviation-safety.net/wikibase/wiki.php?id=18989 |title=ASN Aircraft accident 18-AUG-1970 Aérospatiale SA 318C Alouette II G-AWEE |publisher=''Aviation Safety Network'' |accessdate=4 June 2014}}</ref> * ''[[A Clockwork Orange (film)|A Clockwork Orange]]'' (1971). Producers had to use stock and unused footage, which was dubbed by Rokurô Naya, for the next four episodes, causing a dip in the ratings. Producers eventually had no choice but to substitute him with a second character played by Takeshi Sasaki. Fujioka made a return in Episode 53 ("Monster Jaguarman – Deathmatch by Motorcycle Fight"). As neither actor could be axed, the show ended up having two heroes.{{citation needed|date=September 2011}} *''[[Von Richthofen and Brown]]'' (1971). The following day, another aircraft crashed, injuring pilot [[Lynn Garrison]] and actor [[Don Stroud]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/94914/Von-Richthofen-and-Brown/notes.html |title=''Von Richthofen and Brown'' (1971) - Notes |publisher=[[Turner Classic Movies]] |accessdate=22 May 2014}}</ref> *''[[Deliverance]]'' (1972). Film director [[Brian De Palma]] recalled having to beg Connery to do a second take of the scene.<ref name=klimek>{{cite web|last=Klimek|first=Chris|title='De Palma': An Underrated Director Opens Up About His Work, And His Obsessions|date=9 June 2016|publisher=[[NPR]]|url=https://www.npr.org/2016/06/09/481000877/de-palma-an-underrated-director-opens-up-about-his-work-and-his-obsessions|accessdate=10 September 2017}}</ref><ref name=newman>{{cite web|last=Newman|first=Jason|title=15 Things We Learned From the 'De Palma' Documentary|date=9 June 2016|publisher=''[[Rolling Stone]]''|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/news/15-things-we-learned-from-the-de-palma-documentary-20160609|accessdate=10 September 2017}}</ref> *''[[Braddock: Missing in Action III]]'' (1988). MacFarlane & Company Inc. 2014. p1846</ref> *''[[Back to the Future Part II]]'' (1989). ==1990s==
*''[[Back to the Future Part III]]'' (1990). In the scene where [[List of Back to the Future characters#Buford "Mad Dog" Tannen|Buford "Mad Dog" Tannen]] and his gang roped and hanged [[Marty McFly]], [[Michael J. Fox]] lost consciousness for a few seconds from being hanged before an extra realized he was legitimately being asphyxiated and the noose was lowered. He recorded this event in his autobiography, ''Lucky Man''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://thefilmbox.org/ultimate-facts/ultimate-facts-back-to-the-future-part-iii/2/|title=Ultimate Facts: Back to the Future Part III - Page 2 of 3 - The Film Box|date=2015-06-26|work=The Film Box|access-date=2018-03-18|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name="Cracked"/> *''[[Delta Force 2: The Colombian Connection]]'' (1990). Stuntman Jay C. Currin was killed the first day of filming when a stunt fall off a 55-foot cliff went wrong and he landed on some rocks instead of the airbag that had been placed to break his fall.<ref name="World's Strangest">{{cite web|url=http://www.worldsstrangest.com/mental-floss/the-quick-10-10-film-set-tragedies/|title=The Quick 10|publisher=World's Strangest|accessdate=21 December 2012}}</ref> *''[[Highlander II: The Quickening]]'' (1991). [[Christopher Lambert]] and [[Michael Ironside]] both suffered injuries during filming. Lambert chipped one of Ironside's teeth during a fight scene, while Ironside inadvertently chopped off part of Lambert's finger during a sword fight scene.<ref>{{cite news |title=The pain of realism |first=Thomas D. |last=Elias |agency=Scripps Howard News Service |publisher=Independent Press |date=25 October 1991 |work=St. Petersburg Times |page=4D |issn=1563-6291}}</ref> *''[[Terminator 2: Judgment Day]]'' (1991). [[Linda Hamilton]] suffered permanent hearing damage in one ear during filming when she fired a gun inside an elevator without using her ear plugs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blockbuster.co.uk/bbsitecontent/editorial/promotions/may10/linda-hamilton.aspx |title=Linda Hamilton: Interview |author=Julius, Marshall |publisher=[[Blockbuster LLC|Blockbuster UK]] |accessdate=1 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025062335/http://www.blockbuster.co.uk/bbsitecontent/editorial/promotions/may10/linda-hamilton.aspx |archivedate=25 October 2012 |df= }}</ref> She also injured her knees from falling on the ground during multiple re-shoots of her character being hit with a nightstick by actor Ken Gibbel. Frustrated by Gibbel's refusal to hit her properly, Hamilton legitimately knocked him out with a broom handle during the escape scene.<ref name="Missed">{{cite web|url=http://whatculture.com/film/10-genuine-on-screen-acting-injuries-you-probably-missed?page=11|title=10 Genuine On-Screen Acting Injuries You Probably Missed|author=Gallagher, Simon|date=6 October 2013|publisher=''What Culture''|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170110131109/http://whatculture.com/film/10-genuine-on-screen-acting-injuries-you-probably-missed?page=11|archivedate=10 January 2017|deadurl=yes|accessdate=14 June 2014|df=}}</ref> [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] nearly broke some fingers while twirling his shotgun with one hand. While there was a shotgun with a lever loop lengthened to fit Schwarzenegger's hand, he mistakenly picked up a standard sized unit and injured his hand while attempting the stunt.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.factfiend.com/schwarzenegger-nearly-broke-fingers-filming-terminator-2/ |title=How Schwarzenegger Nearly Broke His Fingers Filming ''Terminator 2'' |author=Smallwood, Karl |publisher=FactFiend.com |accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref> *''[[The Bodyguard (1992 film)|The Bodyguard]]'' (1992). A worker died when he was crushed between two lighting equipment cranes during filming.<ref name="Los Angeles Times"/> * [[Wind (film)|''Wind'']] (1992). Australian stuntman Chris Anderson had to have a leg amputated below the knee after he was severely injured when a 30-foot yacht collided with the jet-boat on which Anderson was eating his lunch during a break in filming.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cargraphics.com.au/car-graphics-articles/1998/4/12/falling-stars/ |title=Falling Stars |author=Schwartz, Larry |publisher=''Car Graphics'' |date=12 April 1998 |accessdate=27 May 2014}}</ref> *''[[999 (UK TV series)|999]]'' (1993). While recreating a real life near-fatal parachute incident in which a parachutist tangled his equipment with the aircraft's landing gear before freeing himself, veteran stuntman [[Tip Tipping]] leapt out of a [[Cessna]] and crashed into woods near [[Ellingham, Northumberland]], he was pronounced dead when medical staff arrived.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/stuntman-killed-in-parachute-jump-1471168.html | location=London | work=The Independent | title=Stuntman killed in parachute jump | date=6 February 1993}}</ref> *''[[Crime Story (film)|Crime Story]]'' (1993). Jackie Chan's legs were crushed between two cars during a dangerous stunt scene.<ref name="I Am Jackie Chan"/> * ''[[The Fugitive (1993 film)|The Fugitive]]'' (1993). [[Harrison Ford]] damaged some ligaments on his leg while filming a chase scene in the woods. Because he refused to have surgery until filming was wrapped, his character Dr. Richard Kimble walked with a limp throughout the film.<ref name="Harrison Ford"/> * ''[[Gettysburg (1993 film)|Gettysburg]]'' (1993). During filming of the battle scenes on [[Little Round Top]], Bradley Egen, an extra playing a Union soldier, was unintentionally struck in the head by the butt of a musket and suffered a severe concussion.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blog.americanhistory.si.edu/osaycanyousee/2012/10/part-ii-my-experience-on-the-set-of-gettysburg.html |title=Part II: My Experience on the set of "Gettysburg" |author=Egen, Brian James |publisher=Smithsonian National Museum of American History |date=19 October 2012 |accessdate=8 June 2014}}</ref> *''[[Sliver (film)|Sliver]]'' (1993). Cameraman Michael Benson suffered lung injuries after a helicopter crash left him trapped for two days inside a Hawaiian volcano crater. The crew aboard the helicopter was flying over an active volcano to shoot the film's original opening sequence, but the footage was lost in the crash.<ref>{{cite news| url= http://articles.latimes.com/1992-11-25/local/me-933_1_woodland-hills | location=Hawaii | work=LA Times | title= Cameraman Stars in Volcano Ordeal : Rescue: Woodland Hills resident is recovering after spending two days trapped in a Hawaiian crater. | date=27 November 1992 | accessdate=26 February 2014 | first=Patrice | last=Apodaca}}</ref> *''[[The Crow (1994 film)|The Crow]]'' (1994). On 31 March 1993, American actor and martial artist [[Brandon Lee]] was accidentally shot and killed in [[North Carolina]] with a [[.44 magnum]] gun that was intended to fire blanks but contained a bullet left behind after a dummy round had been inserted and removed.<ref name="Huffington"/><ref name="HowStuffWorks"/><ref name="World's Strangest"/><ref name="Los Angeles Times"/><ref name="Schanie2010">{{cite book|last=Schanie|first=Andrew|title=Movie Confidential: Sex, Scandal, Murder and Mayhem in the Film Industry|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rYfoLmaa3I4C&pg=PA179|accessdate=4 May 2012|date=1 June 2010|publisher=Clerisy Press|isbn=978-1-57860-354-1|page=179}}</ref> Also, on 1 February 1993 on the opening day of filming a carpenter was severely shocked and burned when his scissor lift struck power lines.<ref name="nine"/> * ''[[Seven (1995 film)|Seven]]'' (1995). In a scene where Detective David Mills ([[Brad Pitt]]) chased John Doe in the rain, Pitt fell and his arm went through a car windscreen, requiring surgery. This accident was written into the script to explain Pitt wearing a cast over his arm. Coincidentally, the original script did call for Pitt's character to be injured during this sequence but not to his hand.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/SHOWBIZ/Movies/9509/seven/ |title="Seven"-- Deadly cinema? |author=Buckland, Carol |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=23 September 1995 |accessdate=19 December 2013}}</ref> *''[[Vampire in Brooklyn]]'' (1995). [[Angela Bassett]]'s stunt double Sonja Davis fell to her death in a stunt gone wrong.<ref name="Brown2010"/> Her death led to a $50 million wrongful-death lawsuit against [[Paramount Pictures]].<ref name="Joshi2010">{{cite book|last=Joshi|first=S. T.|title=Encyclopedia of the Vampire: The Living Dead in Myth, Legend, and Popular Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RSNq99Oa310C&pg=PA346|accessdate=4 May 2012|date=4 November 2010|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-0-313-37833-1|page=346}}</ref> *''[[Waterworld]]'' (1995). During production, actresses [[Jeanne Tripplehorn]] and [[Tina Majorino]] were thrown overboard from the [[trimaran]] they were on when its bowsprit snapped. Nearly a dozen rescue divers jumped in and brought them back on board. [[Kevin Costner]] nearly died when he was caught in a squall while tied to the mast of his trimaran. In addition, several cast and crew members suffered from seasickness and jellyfish stings.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20100733,00.html |title= Kevin Costner's Hawaii Uh-Oh |author=Levitt, Shelley |work=[[People (magazine)|People]] |date=29 May 1995 |accessdate=19 January 2016}}</ref> Costner's stunt double, Laird Hamilton, was lost at sea for a few hours when his jet ski ran out of fuel after the filming of a jet ski scene.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.warpedfactor.com/2015/07/1995-trouble-with-waterworld.html?m=1 |title=1995 - The Trouble With WATERWORLD |publisher=Warped Factor |date=29 July 2015 |accessdate=17 January 2018}}</ref> * ''Ah Kam'' (1996). On October 1995, actress [[Michelle Yeoh]], who usually performs her own stunts, was seriously injured during shooting of the film about the life of a stuntwoman, when she misjudged an {{convert|18|ft|m|adj=on}} jump off a bridge onto a truck. She fractured a vertebra and was in traction for a month. The sequence can be seen at the end of the film.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lovehkfilm.com/reviews/ah_kam.htm|title=The Stuntwoman|work=Lovehkfilm.com|accessdate=5 May 2012}}</ref> * [[Black & Decker]] commercial (1996). Veteran pilot Michael Tamburro died after suffering a broken neck and head injuries in a helicopter crash caused by hitting a main rotor blade on a rock on the side of a desert butte. Co-pilot [[Alan Purwin]] suffered a broken arm, and flying debris from the crash injured a crew member. Producers [[Propaganda Films]] had not obtained a permit to use a helicopter when filming, which the firm claimed was due to an unintentional oversight.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/SHIFT+IN+COPTER%27S+APPROACH+STUDIED+IN+FATAL+CRASH+%3A+PROBE+ALSO...-a083963445|title=Shift in copter's approach studied in fatal crash : Probe also targets firm's failure to file film permit|accessdate=28 January 2015}}</ref> *''[[Love Serenade]]'' (1996). During the filming of a scene on a [[grain silo]], stuntman Collin Dragsbaek (doubling actor George Shetsov) died when he fell onto a faulty airbag.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/entertainment/film/when-actors-drop-dead/2009/10/26/1256405349835.html |title=What directors do when actors drop dead |author=Molitorisz, Sacha |work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=27 October 2009 |accessdate=27 May 2014}}</ref> * ''[[Gone Fishin' (film)|Gone Fishin']]'' (1997). Janet Wilder was killed and four other people, including her husband, were injured when a speedboat driver misjudged a ramp and the speedboat landed in a crowd.<ref>{{cite news|title=Woman Killed in Film Stunt : Accident: Woodland Hills resident was with her stuntman husband when she was struck by a boat.|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1995-12-20/local/me-16074_1_woodland-hills|publisher=''LA Times'' | date=20 December 1995}}</ref> *''[[Pleasantville (film)|Pleasantville]]'' (1997). Cameraman Brent Hershman died when he fell asleep driving home after a 19-hour workday on the set of the film. Hershman's death resulted in a wrongful death suit, claiming that New Line Cinema, New Line Productions and Juno Pix Inc. were responsible for the death as a result of the lengthy work hours imposed on the set, and spurred a call to limit filming hours.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.vulture.com/2012/05/how-long-are-the-days-on-a-movie-set-polone.html | title=Polone: The Unglamorous, Punishing Hours of Working on a Hollywood Set | work=Vulture | date=May 23, 2012 | accessdate=August 6, 2013 |last1=Polone |first1=Gavin |authorlink1=Gavin Polone}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://articles.latimes.com/1997/dec/21/local/me-995 | title=Death After Long Workday Spurs Suit | work=Los Angeles Times | date=December 21, 1997 | accessdate=August 6, 2013 |last1=O'Neill |first1=Ann W.}}</ref> *''[[Titanic (1997 film)|Titanic]]'' (1997). Several extras were injured during the film's climactic sinking scene where passengers fell and hit parts of the ship. Injuries ranged from a broken ankle to cracked ribs, a fractured cheekbone, and a ruptured spleen.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sabotagetimes.com/reportage/james-cameron-and-the-incredible-untold-story-behind-titanic/ |title=James Cameron and The Incredible Untold Story Behind Titanic |author=Luck, Richard |publisher=''Sabotage Times'' |date=26 March 2012 |accessdate=15 December 2014}}</ref> [[Kate Winslet]] suffered pneumonia from filming the water scenes after she refused to wear a wetsuit under her dress. During the scene where Jack and Rose were running away from an ocean wave in the hallways, Winslet's coat snagged on a gate, pulling her down and nearly drowning her.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ivillage.com/kate-winslet-titanic-near-death-experience/1-a-65864 |title=Kate Winslet's Near-Death Experience During 'Titanic' |author=Kaufman, Donna |publisher=[[iVillage]] |date=13 November 2009 |accessdate=15 December 2014}}</ref> On the final night of shooting in [[Nova Scotia]], 80 cast and crew members were hospitalized after pranksters spiked the clam chowder at the catering area with [[Phencyclidine|PCP]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/mjs538/things-you-didnt-know-about-titanic |title=33 Things You Didn't Know About the Movie ''Titanic'' |author=Stopera, Matt |publisher=[[BuzzFeed]] |date=31 March 2012 |accessdate=15 December 2014}}</ref> *''[[Blues Brothers 2000]]'' (1998). While filming a stunt scene, a car rolled onto two crew members, one of whom needed a leg amputation. Three months later, during filming for a car crash sequence, stuntman Bob Minor suffered severe injuries to his head.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Movies/Artists/A/Aykroyd_Dan/1997/10/22/756444.html |title=Blues Brothers mishaps spark second probe |publisher=''Canoe.ca'' |accessdate=20 January 2014}}</ref> *''Galápagos: The Enchanted Voyage'' (1998). Noel Archambault, the film's camera operator/stereographer, was killed in an ultralight aircraft crash along with the pilot, William Raisner Jr., while filming in the [[Galápagos Islands]]. The men were found at an elevation of 3,000 feet on [[Cerro Azul (Ecuador volcano)|Cerro Azul]], one of the two most active volcanoes in the archipelago.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/1998/film/news/cameraman-dies-in-crash-1117478104/ |title=Cameraman dies in crash |publisher="Variety" |date=2 July 1998 |accessdate=12 January 2015}}</ref> *''[[Mighty Joe Young (1998 film)|Mighty Joe Young]]'' (1998). Director of photography Don Peterman and camera operator Ray de la Motte were injured while preparing a crane shot in July 1997 in [[Thousand Oaks, California]]. Both suffered extensive neck and head injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/34798/two-hurt-on-mighty-joe-young-shoot |title=Two Hurt on "Mighty Joe Young" Shoot |work=Eonline.com |accessdate=5 March 2014}}</ref>
==2000s== *''[[Cast Away]]'' (2000). While filming, [[Tom Hanks]] cut his leg. Two weeks later, the swelling on his leg persisted, and Hanks was confined to a hospital for three weeks to treat a [[Staphylococcus|staph infection]] that would have killed him from blood poisoning.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cinemablend.com/pop/Hanks-Almost-Died-While-Filming-Castaway-7381.html |title=Hanks Almost Died While Filming ''Cast Away'' |author=Celeb Staink |publisher=CinemaBlend |accessdate=15 December 2014}}</ref> *''[[Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon]]'' (2000). On August 25, 2016, a construction worker was killed while dismantling one of the film's sets at Origo Studios in [[Budapest]], Hungary.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/blade-runner-2-construction-worker-killed-after-set-collapses-in-hungary-a7211206.html |title='Blade Runner 2': Construction worker killed after set collapses in Hungary |author=Buncombe, Andrew |work=[[The Independent]] |date=26 August 2016 |accessdate=20 December 2016}}</ref> *''[[A Dog's Purpose (film)|A Dog's Purpose]]'' (2017). In 2017, a video was released that took place during filming in 2015, where a [[German Shepherd]] named Hercules was submerged under a rushing current while the crew rushed towards him. This was also the subject of controversy as the video shown by [[TMZ]] also features a man holding Hercules by the collar and leading him into the water, this leading to accusations of [[animal abuse|manhandling]].<ref>[http://en.yibada.com/articles/188421/20170123/dog-s-purpose-premiere-cancelled-due-video-controversy-peta-call.htm Dog's Purpose premiere cancelled due to video controversy]</ref> According to the director [[Lasse Hallström]], Hercules is "happy and healthy".
*''[[The Fate of the Furious]]'' (2017). During [[principal photography]] in [[Mývatn]], [[Iceland]], on March 14, 2016, strong winds sent a plastic iceberg prop flying into a paddock and striking two horses. One was wounded and the other mortally injured; it was later euthanized.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tmz.com/2016/03/14/fast-and-furious-8-horse-iceberg-dead/#ixzz42y55LYUO |title=''Fast & Furious 8'' Horse Killed By Flying 'Iceberg' |publisher=[[TMZ]] |date=14 March 2016 |accessdate=12 December 2016}}</ref> *''[[The Grand Tour (TV series)|The Grand Tour]]'' (2017). While filming in [[Mozambique]] for the series' second season, Richard Hammond was seriously injured after falling off his motorbike.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/tvandshowbiz/3128576/grand-tour-presenter-richard-hammond-badly-hurt-in-motorbike-crash-in-remote-mozambique-after-almost-dying-in-top-gear-collision-11-years-ago/ |title= HAMSTER'S 2ND HORROR CRASH Grand Tour presenter Richard Hammond badly hurt in motorbike crash in remote Mozambique after almost dying in Top Gear collision 11 years ago |author=Davies, Howell |work=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]] |date=19 March 2017 |accessdate=2 April 2017}}</ref> While filming another segment on June 10, 2017, Hammond was hospitalized after crashing a [[Rimac Concept One]] during a [[hillclimbing]] event in Switzerland. Hammond was able to escape the accident with a fractured knee, despite the car flipping and catching fire shortly afterwards. The crash footage was shown in the first episode of the second season.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.sky.com/story/ex-top-gear-star-richard-hammond-in-hospital-after-car-crash-report-10911123 |title=Richard Hammond in hospital after car crash |work=Sky News |date=10 June 2017 |accessdate=30 June 2017}}</ref> *''[[Prison Break (season 5)|Prison Break]]'' (2017). On June 1, 2016, [[Dominic Purcell]] suffered a broken nose and a head injury on set in [[Morocco]] after an iron bar used as a set piece had fallen onto his head. Purcell was immediately airlifted from [[Marrakesh]] to [[Casablanca]] for treatment where he recovered.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BGH85F8nAY8/ |title=Dominic Purcell: I'm good |last=Purcell |first=Dominic |website=[[Instagram]] |date=1 June 2016 |accessdate=27 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2016/06/dominic-purcell-injured-on-set-prison-break-production-not-impacted-1201766656/ |title=Dominic Purcell Injured On Set Of Fox's ''Prison Break'', Production Not Impacted |last=Andreeva |first=Nellie |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=3 June 2016 |accessdate=27 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/celebrity-life/prison-break-star-dominic-purcell-almost-killed-on-set-after-iron-bar-falls-on-his-head/news-story/4d77666d5c1f5876da2ed081ef51133c |title=''Prison Break'' star Dominic Purcell almost killed on set after iron bar falls on his head |publisher=News.com.au |date=4 June 2016 |accessdate=27 January 2018}}</ref> *''[[Resident Evil: The Final Chapter]]'' (2017). Stunt double [[Olivia Jackson]] was severely injured in a motorcycle accident on set in South Africa in September 2015, leaving her in a medically-induced coma for two weeks. During a high-speed motorcycle chase, she collided with a camera arm. Among Jackson's injuries were cerebral trauma, a crushed and [[Degloving|degloved]] face, a severed artery in her neck, a paralyzed arm, several broken ribs, a shattered scapula, a broken clavicle, torn fingers with a thumb that needed to be amputated, and five nerves torn out of her spinal cord.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2015/10/stuntwoman-seriously-injured-on-set-of-resident-evil-the-final-chapter-1201520953/ |title='Resident Evil' Stuntwoman Injured On Set Out Of Coma – Update |author1=Robb, David |author2=Busch, Anita |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=13 October 2015 |accessdate=21 October 2015}}</ref> Her paralyzed left arm was amputated in June 2016.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.focus.de/kultur/vermischtes/milla-jovovich-milla-jovovichs-stuntfrau-verliert-ihren-arm_id_5610472.html |title=''Star Wars'' Milla Jovovichs Stuntfrau verliert ihren Arm |work=[[Focus (German magazine)|Focus]] |date=9 June 2016 |accessdate=9 June 2016}}</ref> Days after Jackson's accident, crew member Ricardo Cornelius was crushed to death by a [[Hummer H1]] that slid off a platform he was operating.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/film/movie-news/man-killed-set-of-resident-evil/ |title=Crew member crushed to death on ''Resident Evil: The Final Chapter'' set |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=24 December 2015 |accessdate=17 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-4130008/Resident-Evil-stunt-woman-reveals-twisted-crash.html |title=Resident Evil stunt woman who had her arm amputated after motorcycle crash on set bravely reveals her scars after horrific accident |author=Smith, Jennifer |publisher=''[[Daily Mail]]'' |date=18 January 2017 |accessdate=16 August 2017}}</ref> *''[[The Walking Dead (TV series)|The Walking Dead]]'' (2017). On July 13, 2017, stuntman [[John Bernecker]] suffered a head injury after falling more than 20 feet off a balcony onto a concrete floor while filming a stunt for the show. He died the following day.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://variety.com/2017/tv/news/walking-dead-stuntman-dead-dies-john-bernecker-1202495620/ | title='Walking Dead' Stuntman Dies After On-Set Accident |author=Otterson, Joe |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=14 July 2017 |accessdate=15 July 2017}}</ref> *''[[Deadpool 2]]'' (2018). On August 14, 2017, stuntwoman [[Joi Harris|Joi "SJ" Harris]] was killed during filming after losing control of a motorcycle while turning a corner and crashing through a glass window.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Patten|first1=Dominic|title='Deadpool 2' Stunt Death Came After Multiple Takes & Long Shooting Days|url=http://deadline.com/2017/08/deadpool-2-stunt-driver-killed-on-set-vancouver-1202148277/|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=14 August 2017}}</ref><ref name="StuntWomanDeath">{{cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2017/08/deadpool-2-stunt-driver-killed-on-set-vancouver-1202148277/|title='Deadpool 2' Stunt Crash Victim ID'd As First African-American Female Pro Road Racer; Director & Fox "Deeply Saddened" – Update|last1=Patten|first1=Dominic|last2=Busch|first2=Anita|last3=Robb|first3=David|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=14 August 2017|accessdate=15 August 2017|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6sjL67i2Y?url=http://deadline.com/2017/08/deadpool-2-stunt-driver-killed-on-set-vancouver-1202148277/|archivedate=15 August 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="Comingsoon">{{cite web |url=http://www.comingsoon.net/movies/news/879375-deadpool-2-stunt-person-killed-tom-cruise-injured-in-mi-6-stunt-gone-wrong |title=Deadpool 2 Stunt Person Killed, Tom Cruise Injured in M:I 6 Stunt Gone Wrong |author=Evry, Max |publisher=Comingsoon.net |date=14 August 2017 |accessdate=16 August 2017}}</ref> *''[[Ghostland]]'' (2018). In December 2016, actress [[Taylor Hickson]] crashed through a glass door while filming a scene, causing massive injuries to her face and requiring multiple reconstructive surgeries. She now has a permanent facial scar as a result of the incident.<ref name="Hickson">{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2018/03/taylor-hickson-injury-lawsuit-ghostland-facial-injury-disfigured-1202312643/ |title=Actress Taylor Hickson Sues Producers Over Disfiguring Injury |accessdate=7 March 2018 |last=Robb |first=David |date=6 March 2018 |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]}}</ref> *''[[Maze Runner: The Death Cure]]'' (2018). On 17 March 2016, actor [[Dylan O'Brien]] suffered multiple injuries on set after being run over by a car in a scene gone wrong and was taken to hospital in Vancouver.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Breznican|first1=Anthony|title=Dylan O'Brien injured on set of Maze Runner: The Death Cure|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/03/18/dylan-obrien-injured-set-maze-runner-death-cure|accessdate=18 March 2016|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=18 March 2016}}</ref> Production was stopped after the accident.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Zumberge|first1=Marianne|title='Maze Runner' Star Dylan O'Brien Injured on Set|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/dylan-obrien-maze-runner-injury-1201733916/|accessdate=18 March 2016|work=Variety|date=18 March 2016}}</ref> *''[[Motherless Brooklyn (film)|Motherless Brooklyn]]'' (2019). On March 22, 2018, a fire broke out on one of the film's sets in New York CIty. The resulting blaze killed firefighter Lieutenant Michael Davidson.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2018/03/23/nyc-firefighter-dies-battling-blaze-on-set-bruce-willis-edward-norton-film-motherless-brooklyn.html |title=NYC firefighter dies battling blaze on set of Bruce Willis, Edward Norton film 'Motherless Brooklyn' |last=Re |first=Gregg |last2=Savitsky |first2=Sasha |date=23 March 2018 |website=[[Fox News]] |accessdate=28 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.screendaily.com/news/production-suspended-on-motherless-brooklyn-after-firefighter-death/5127763.article |title=Production suspended on 'Motherless Brooklyn' after firefighter death |last=Kay |first=Jeremy |date=23 March 2018 |website=[[Screen Daily]] |accessdate=28 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.screendaily.com/news/tenants-sue-edward-nortons-company-over-set-fire/5127836.article |title=Tenants sue Edward Norton's company over set fire |last=Kay |first=Jeremy |date=27 March 2018 |website=Screen Daily |access-date=28 September 2018}}</ref> *''The Story of Taiwan'' (2019). Director [[Chi Po-lin]], his assistant Chen Kuan-chi, and pilot Chang Chi-kuang were killed in a helicopter crash on 10 June 2017 while shooting aerial footage in a mountainous area in [[Hualien County]]'s [[Fengbin, Hualien|Fengbin Township]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/front/archives/2017/06/11/2003672325 |title=Filmmaker dies in Hualien crash |author=Chung, Jake |publisher=''[[Taipei Times]]'' |date=10 June 2017 |accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref> *''Ilyinskye Frontier'' (2019). Russian stuntman Oleg Shilkin, 31, was run over and killed by a vintage tank during filming of the movie set in [[World War II]]. The incident happened on the set located 120 miles outside Moscow. The tank was meant to halt a short distance from where Shilkin was but the tank failed to stop in time.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.msn.com/en-au/entertainment/celebrity/stuntman-is-crushed-to-death-by-nazi-tank-while-filming-a-world-war-two-movie-in-russia/ar-BBOPUzu?ocid=sf |title=Stuntman is crushed to death by Nazi tank while filming a World War Two movie in Russia |author=Stewart, Will |publisher=''[[Daily Mail]]''/[[MSN]] |date=24 October 2018 |accessdate=25 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/russian-stuntman-minced-nazi-tank-13472678 |title=Stuntman 'MINCED' by Nazi tank as film scene goes horrifically wrong |author=Kindon, Frances |publisher=''[[Daily Mirror]]'' |date=24 October 2018 |accessdate=25 October 2018}}</ref>

The '''''Lucky-S'' incident''' occurred on January 7, 1993 when [[Turkish Navy]] vessels, carrying members of the [[Turkish Police|Turkish Narcotic Police]], intercepted the MV ''Lucky-S'', a Turkish ocean freighter in international waters in the [[Mediterranean Sea]]. The ship was suspected of being involved in smuggling illegal drugs into [[Turkey]].<ref name="tg1">{{cite web |url=http://www.tumgazeteler.com/?a=1345912 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717113237/http://www.tumgazeteler.com/?a=1345912 |title=''Kısmetim 1'' Davasında Yeni Karar |archivedate=July 17, 2011 |accessdate=January 18, 2009 |language=Turkish }}</ref>
It was the second Turkish anti-drug-smuggling operation on the high seas in three weeks, following the [[Kısmetim-1 incident]]. {{convert|11039.550|kg|lb|abbr=on}} [[cannabis (drug)|cannabis]] and {{convert|2568.010|kg|lb|abbr=on}} [[morphine|morphine base]]<ref name="tg1"/> were captured on the ship, which was escorted to a Turkish port.
== Trial == A total of 11 individuals arrested as a result of the operation were convicted of involvement in the drug trade.<ref name="ans">{{cite web |url=http://ansiklopedi.turkcebilgi.com/Halil_Havar |publisher=Ansiklopedi |title=Halil Havar Hakkında Bilgi |accessdate=January 18, 2009 |language=Turkish }}</ref>
[[Nejat Daş]], who was also found to have organized [[drug trafficking]] by the MV ''Kısmetim-1'' and was imprisoned, escaped from custody on November 8, 1994, as he was brought from [[Sinop Fortress Prison]] to the 1st State Security Court in [[Istanbul]] for trial over his involvement in the Lucky-S incident. On March 16, 1995, he was sentenced in absentia to 24 years' imprisonment in a maximum-security prison.<ref name="tg1"/>
It was asserted that the drug on the ship belonged mostly to the Turkish [[drug lord]] [[Halil Havar]], son of the [[arms trafficking|arms trafficker]] Mehmet Havar. He was tried and sentenced to 30 years' imprisonment. He is serving his sentence in the maximum-security Uşak Prison.<ref name="ans"/>

{{Purges in the Soviet Union}} '''Mass operations of the NKVD'''<ref>[[Vadim Rogovin]] "The Party of the Executed" (1997) {{ISBN|5-85272-026-7}}, [http://web.mit.edu/fjk/Public/Rogovin/volume5/i.html Chapter 1: "Mass Operations"] {{ru icon}}</ref> were carried out during the [[Great Purge]] and targeted specific categories of people. As a rule, they were carried out according to the corresponding order of the [[People's Commissar]] of Internal Affairs [[Nikolai Yezhov]].
*[[Kulak|Ex-kulaks, criminals, and other anti-Soviet elements]] ~386,798 killed<ref>{{Cite book|title=Bloodlands: Europe Between Hitler and Stalin|last=Snyder|first=Timothy|publisher=Basic Books|year=2012|isbn=978-0465002399|location=|pages=81}}</ref> **[[NKVD Order no. 00447]] *[[Traitor of Motherland Family Member]]s **[[NKVD Order no. 00486]] *[[Kharbin operation of the NKVD]] ~30,992 killed<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-news-from-elsewhere-28604779| title=Ukraine: Secret service publishes Stalin files}}</ref> **[[NKVD Order no. 00593]]
== National operations of the NKVD ==
The operations of this type in this period targeted "foreign" ethnicities (ethnicities with cross-border ties to foreign [[nation-states]]), unlike [[Population transfer in the Soviet Union|nationally targeted repressions]] during [[World War II]].
* [[Polish Operation of the NKVD]] ~111,091 killed<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.grhs.org/heritage/SovietRepression.pdf | title=Soviet "Paradise" Revisited: Genocide, Dissent, Memory and Denial | publisher=GRHS Heritage Society | accessdate=April 26, 2011 | author=Eric J. Schmaltz | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111018085732/http://www.grhs.org/heritage/SovietRepression.pdf | archivedate=October 18, 2011 | df= }}</ref> ** [[NKVD Order № 00485]] * [[German Operation of the NKVD]] ~41,898 killed<ref>Н.Охотин, А.Рогинский, Москва. Из истории "немецкой операции" НКВД 1937-1938 гг.[http://www.memo.ru/history/nem/Chapter2.htm Chapter 2]</ref> ** [[NKVD Order № 00439]] * [[Greek Operation of NKVD]] ~20,000<ref name="Greeks of the Steppe">{{cite web|publisher=Washington Post| title=Greeks of the steppe | date=November 12, 2012| author=[[Will Englund]]|accessdate=30 June 2018| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/greeks-of-the-steppe/2012/11/10/b7ff79de-24ec-11e2-9313-3c7f59038d93_story.html?noredirect=on&utm_term=.eac697245efe}}</ref>—50,000 {{sfn|Agtzidis|1991|p=372—382}} * [[Latvian Operation of the NKVD]] * [[Deportation of Koreans in the Soviet Union|Korean Operation of the NKVD]] ~1/4 of the entire Soviet Korean population killed<ref>{{cite book| url=https://books.google.com.sg/books?id=kf8QBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA68| title= Front CoveRights, Deportation, and Detention in the Age of Immigration Control | author=Tom K. Wong | publisher=Stanford University Press| page=68}}</ref> * [[Romanian Operation of the NKVD]] * [[Estonian Operation of the NKVD]] * [[Finnish Operation of the NKVD]]
== Rollback ==
On November 17, 1938 a joint decree No. 81 of [[Sovnarkom]] [[USSR]] and [[Central Committee]] of [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] [[Decree about Arrests, Prosecutor Supervision and Course of Investigation]] and the subsequent order of the NKVD undersigned by [[Lavrentiy Beria]] cancelled most of NKVD orders of mass type (but not all, see, e.g., [[NKVD Order no. 00689]]) and suspended implementation of death sentences, signifying the end of the [[Great Purge]] ("Yezhovshchina").

{{Infobox film festival | name = Okinawa International Movie Festival | logo = Okinawa International Movie Festival logo.png | image = 3rd Okinawa International Movie Festival 001.jpg | image_size = | caption = Main stage at the 3rd Okinawa International Movie Festival, 2011 | number = | location = [[Okinawa Island]], Japan | language = International | website = http://www.oimf.jp }}
The '''Okinawa International Movie Festival''' is an annual [[Film Festival]] held in [[Ginowan]] City and [[Naha]] City on the Japanese island of [[Okinawa Island]]. The festival was founded by Japanese century-old comedy-entertainment giant [[Yoshimoto Kogyo]] in 2009 and focuses on comedy films from around the world, with the theme of "Laugh & Peace".<ref name="Hollywood Reporter">{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/okinawa-intl-movie-fest-open-303725 | title=Okinawa Intl Movie Fest to Open for Fun in the Sun| author= Gavin J. Blair | work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] | date=2012-03-23 |accessdate=2012-12-30}}</ref>
It is held each year at the [[Okinawa Convention Center]] and Sakurazaka Theater with indoor and outdoor screenings of film premieres and recent movies from Japan and abroad. It also hosts fashion, music and trade shows and has been likened to a Japanese ''[[matsuri]]'' in atmosphere.<ref name="Eye">{{cite web |url=http://www.midnighteye.com/features/okinawa-movie-festival-2012/ | title=Okinawa Movie Festival 2012| author= J.M. Hammond | publisher=Midnight Eye | date=2012-10-06 |accessdate=2012-12-30}}</ref>
The most prestigious award given out at the Okinawa International Movie Festival is the ''Golden [[Shisa]] Award'' for the best film, selected by a jury.
The 8th Okinawa International Film Festival was held from April 21, 2016 until April 24, 2016.<ref>[http://www.oimf.jp/ official website]</ref>
==History== [[File:2nd Okinawa International Movie Festival 002.jpg|thumb|right|Local performers on the red carpet at the 2nd Okinawa International Movie Festival, 2010]] The concept for the festival was inspired by a visit to [[Cannes Film Festival]] by [[Yoshimoto Kogyo]] CEO Hiroshi Osaki. While watching the premiere of [[Hitoshi Matsumoto]]'s ''[[Dai Nipponjin]]'' he considered that the cost of making a film was higher than of putting on a festival, and so to allow people to enjoy watching films, perhaps his company could arrange their own.<ref name="SBS">{{cite web |url=http://www.sbs.com.au/films/movie-news/896243/Okinawa-International-Movie-Festival-Wrap-up | title=Okinawa International Movie Festival: Wrap-up | author= Russell Edwards | publisher=[[Special Broadcasting Service|SBS]] | date=2012-04-03 |accessdate=2012-12-30}}</ref>
[[Yoshimoto Kogyo]], which was started by Sei and Kichibei Yoshimoto in 1912 with a ''[[rakugo]]'' theater in the grounds Tenmangu Shrine in [[Osaka]], had been expanding throughout the 2000s with hundreds of new comedians graduating each year from New Star Creation, Yoshimoto's entertainment school. In addition it had spread out to manage athletes, producers and musicians, and two theatres in each of Tokyo and Osaka.<ref name="FYI">{{cite web |url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/nn20100518i1.html | title=Entertaining the nation | author= Alex Martin | publisher=[[The Japan Times]] | date=2010-05-18 |accessdate=2012-12-30}}</ref>
With [[Busan Film Festival]] director Kim Dong-ho as a patron for the Okinawa International Movie Festival, he was able to give valuable advice while other staff brought expertise from [[Tokyo International Film Festival]].<ref name="SBS"/> The [[1st Okinawa International Movie Festival]] took place over four days from March 19–22, 2009 at the American Village at Mihama Chatan-cho in [[Okinawa City]].
The location of Okinawa was selected for its natural beauty by the sea in order to replicate the atmosphere of Cannes, but with comedy at its heart.<ref name="WSJ">{{cite web |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/scene/2012/03/21/laughter-rules-at-okinawas-international-movie-festival/ | title=Laughter Rules at Okinawa’s Movie Fest | author= Robert Michael Poole | publisher=[[Wall Street Journal]] | date=2012-03-21 |accessdate=2012-12-30}}</ref>
Before each screening, every film is introduced by one of comedy agency giant and organizer [[Yoshimoto Kogyo]]'s comedians.<ref name="ShiftEast">{{cite web | url=http://www.shifteast.com/fourth-okinawan-international-movie-festival/ | title= Fourth Okinawa International Movie Festival | author= Darrell Nelson | publisher= Shift East | date=2012-03-28 |accessdate=2012-12-30}}</ref>
The festival's largest screen is shipped over from Sweden and placed directly on the beach at [[Okinawa Convention Center]]. It measures just under 30m wide and 15m tall.<ref name="ShiftEast"/>
==Programmes== [[File:2nd Okinawa International Movie Festival 003.jpg|thumb|right|Comedians and guests on stage at the 2nd Okinawa International Movie Festival, 2010]] The Okinawa International Movie Festival is organised into two main sections: *'''Laugh''' – The first half is a selection of comedy films from around the world. *'''Peace''' – The second half includes dramas and documentaries.
==Juries == Prior to the beginning of each event, the Festival's board of directors appoints the juries who hold sole responsibility for choosing which films will receive a Cannes award. Jurors are chosen from a wide range of international artists, based on their body of work and respect from their peers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/festival/juries|title= Cannes juries|publisher=Cannes Festival website}}</ref>
* Feature Films – An international jury composed of a President and various film or art personalities, who determine the prizes for the feature films in Competition.
==Awards== The most prestigious award given out at the Okinawa International Movie Festival is the ''Golden [[Shisa]] Award'' for the best film.
In addition the Uminchu Prize Grand Prix is awarded to the best film in each of the two categories. *'''Competition''' ** ''Laugh Category Uminchu Prize Grand Prix'' ** ''Peace Category Uminchu Prize Grand Prix''
